Authors: Lu Y., Xu J., Zhao Y., Ye P., Li H.
Title: Optimal control of wind power hybrid energy storage system
Source title: 1st International Conference on Electronics Instrumentation and Information Systems, EIIS 2017
Affiliations: School of Electrical Engineering, Shenyang University of Technology, Shenyang, China
Authors with affiliations: Lu, Y., School of Electrical Engineering, Shenyang University of Technology, Shenyang, China; Xu, J., School of Electrical Engineering, Shenyang University of Technology, Shenyang, China; Zhao, Y., School of Electrical Engineering, Shenyang University of Technology, Shenyang, China; Ye, P., School of Electrical Engineering, Shenyang University of Technology, Shenyang, China; Li, H., School of Electrical Engineering, Shenyang University of Technology, Shenyang, China
Abstract: Using energy storage system is an effective measure to compensate wind power fluctuation. Wind power was decomposed into low frequency, sub-high frequency and high frequency. Hybrid storage energy system was used to compensate sub-high frequency and high frequency section. Besides, fuzzy sliding control strategy of hybrid energy storage system was set. Fuzzy controller can eliminate chattering of sliding controller. At last, wind power hybrid energy storage system simulation model was built on MATLAB/SIMULINK. According to step response of control system under disturbance, fuzzy sliding controller is verified to have high immunity performance. What's more, the effectiveness of the hybrid energy storage system controller is verified by the fluctuation range and the state of charge(SOC)of energy storage system. © 2017 IEEE.

Authors: Zou K., Wang Y., Li H., Li X.
Title: XORiM: A case of in-memory bit-comparator implementation and its performance implications
Source title: Proceedings of the Asia and South Pacific Design Automation Conference, ASP-DAC
Affiliations: SKLCA, Institute of Computing Technology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, 100190, China; University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, 100049, China
Authors with affiliations: Zou, K., SKLCA, Institute of Computing Technology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, 100190, China, University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, 100049, China; Wang, Y., SKLCA, Institute of Computing Technology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, 100190, China, University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, 100049, China; Li, H., SKLCA, Institute of Computing Technology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, 100190, China, University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, 100049, China; Li, X., SKLCA, Institute of Computing Technology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, 100190, China, University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, 100049, China
Abstract: The resurrection of Processing in memory (PIM) architectures is expected to address the ever-worsening memory wall issue in big data era. In this work, we propose XORiM, an inexpensive PIM design to achieve fast bulky bitwise XOR operation in commodity DRAM devices for memory-intensive workloads. Instead of resorting to 3D-integration or emerging memory technology, we reuse and adapt the peripheral circuits and row-buffers in memory to enable within-DRAM data manipulation. The implemented mechanism can also be employed to conduct high-throughput bulky data operations including memory initialization, AND, OR and INV. We present the detailed circuitry design and transistor-level simulation to evaluate the proposed method, and demonstrate the application of XO-RiM to realistic workloads by conducting full-system level simulation. The experimental results on data-intensive applications such as deduplication and data encryption show that about 1.5× and 5.1× overall performance benefits and 4.9× and 9.1× overall energy savings are achieved respectively by XORiM over conventional computing systems. © 2018 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Big data; Comparator circuits; Computer aided design; Cryptography; Energy conservation; Integrated circuit design; Data manipulations; Data-intensive application; Emerging memory technologies; Performance benefits; Peripheral circuits; Processing in memory; System level simulation; Transistor-level simulation; Dynamic random access storage

Source title: FPGA 2018 - Proceedings of the 2018 ACM/SIGDA International Symposium on Field-Programmable Gate Arrays
Affiliations: National University of Defense Technology, College of Computer, National Key Laboratory for Parallel and Distributed Processing, Changsha, Hunan, China
Authors with affiliations: Shen, J., National University of Defense Technology, College of Computer, National Key Laboratory for Parallel and Distributed Processing, Changsha, Hunan, China; Huang, Y., National University of Defense Technology, College of Computer, National Key Laboratory for Parallel and Distributed Processing, Changsha, Hunan, China; Wang, Z., National University of Defense Technology, College of Computer, National Key Laboratory for Parallel and Distributed Processing, Changsha, Hunan, China; Qiao, Y., National University of Defense Technology, College of Computer, National Key Laboratory for Parallel and Distributed Processing, Changsha, Hunan, China; Wen, M., National University of Defense Technology, College of Computer, National Key Laboratory for Parallel and Distributed Processing, Changsha, Hunan, China; Zhang, C., National University of Defense Technology, College of Computer, National Key Laboratory for Parallel and Distributed Processing, Changsha, Hunan, China
Abstract: Three-dimensional convolutional neural networks (3D CNNs) are used efficiently in many computer vision applications. Most previous work in this area has concentrated only on designing and optimizing accelerators for 2D CNN, with few attempts made to accelerate 3D CNN on FPGA. We find accelerating 3D CNNs on FPGA to be challenge due to their high computational complexity and storage demands. More importantly, although the computation patterns of 2D and 3D CNNs are analogous, the conventional approaches adopted for accelerating 2D CNNs may be unfit for 3D CNN acceleration. In this paper, in order to accelerate 2D and 3D CNNs using a uniform framework, we propose a uniform template-based architecture that uses templates based on the Winograd algorithm to ensure fast development of 2D and 3D CNN accelerators. Furthermore, we also develop a uniform analytical model to facilitate efficient design space explorations of 2D and 3D CNN accelerators based on our architecture. Finally, we demonstrate the effectiveness of the template-based architecture by implementing accelerators for real-life 2D and 3D CNNs (VGG16 and C3D) on multiple FPGA platforms. On S2C VUS440, we achieve up to 1.13 TOPS and 1.11 TOPS under low resource utilization for VGG16 and C3D, respectively. End-to-end comparisons with CPU and GPU solutions demonstrate that our implementation of C3D achieves gains of up to 13x and 60x in performance and energy relative to a CPU solution, and a 6.4x energy efficiency gain over a GPU solution. © 2018 Association for Computing Machinery.
Author Keywords: 3D CNN; Uniform Templates; Winograd Algorithm
Index Keywords: Acceleration; Energy efficiency; Integrated circuit design; Logic gates; Network architecture; Neural networks; 3D CNN; Computer vision applications; Conventional approach; Convolutional neural network; Efficient design space explorations; Resource utilizations; Uniform Templates; Winograd; Field programmable gate arrays (FPGA)

Authors: Galea F., Casha O., Grech I., Gatt E., Micallef J.
Title: A CMOS MPPT power conditioning circuit for energy harvesters
Source title: ICECS 2017 - 24th IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Circuits and Systems
Affiliations: Department of Microelectronics and Nanoelectronics, University of Malta, Msida, Malta
Authors with affiliations: Galea, F., Department of Microelectronics and Nanoelectronics, University of Malta, Msida, Malta; Casha, O., Department of Microelectronics and Nanoelectronics, University of Malta, Msida, Malta; Grech, I., Department of Microelectronics and Nanoelectronics, University of Malta, Msida, Malta; Gatt, E., Department of Microelectronics and Nanoelectronics, University of Malta, Msida, Malta; Micallef, J., Department of Microelectronics and Nanoelectronics, University of Malta, Msida, Malta
Abstract: This paper presents the design of an ultra-low power consumption power conditioning circuit with an analogue maximum power point tracker to maximize the scavenged power generated by energy harvesting devices. Excess power is stored in a large storage capacitor to be used once the power generated by the harvester falls below the power required by the load. The circuit was designed to work with various types of energy harvesters such as solar cells and piezoelectric devices, thus making it compatible with both AC and DC input voltages. The AC/DC-to-DC converter topology employed, does not make use of any rectifier, in order to maximize the power efficiency of the converter. This power conditioner was designed using the AMS High Voltage 0.35 pm CMOS technology. The power conditioner cold starts with a minimum input voltage of 1 V and can subsequently operate with a wide voltage range of 0.2 V to 50 V to be compatible with various types of harvesters. It consumes 250 nW and can work with harvesters capable of generating power in the microwatt and milliwatt range. © 2017 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Charge Controller; Energy Harvesting; Low Power; MPPT; Power Conditioning Circuit; Scavenging Devices
Index Keywords: CMOS integrated circuits; Energy harvesting; HVDC power transmission; Low power electronics; Maximum power point trackers; Timing circuits; Charge controllers; Converter topologies; Energy harvesting device; Low Power; Power conditioners; Power conditioning; Storage capacitor; Ultra-low power consumption; Electric rectifiers

Authors: Zhang J., Tao X., Zhang X., Wu H.
Title: Energy-aware user association in heterogeneous networks with renewable energy supplies
Source title: IEEE International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications, PIMRC
Affiliations: Beijing University of Posts and Telecommunications, Beijing, 100876, China
Authors with affiliations: Zhang, J., Beijing University of Posts and Telecommunications, Beijing, 100876, China; Tao, X., Beijing University of Posts and Telecommunications, Beijing, 100876, China; Zhang, X., Beijing University of Posts and Telecommunications, Beijing, 100876, China; Wu, H., Beijing University of Posts and Telecommunications, Beijing, 100876, China
Abstract: To alleviate the burden on power grid in heterogeneous cellular networks, energy harvesting (EH) has inspired thorough research in both academia and industry. However, the mismatched distribution of energy storage and traffic load leads to a bad result that the renewable energy can not be utilized sufficiently. To tackle this issue, we propose an energy-biased-received-power (EBRP) scheme (i.e., users incline to associate with BSs at higher energy level) for energy-load balancing and on-grid energy saving. Taking into account the dynamic EH behavior, a performance analysis of coverage probability and energy efficiency is conducted in a two-tier heterogeneous network with EH enabled personal cells. Numerical and simulation results are provided along with the maximum-biased-received-power (MBRP) scheme. Numerical results show that the reduction of maximum transmit power at base stations is favorable for enhancing energy efficiency. Moreover, it is revealed that the proposed scheme shows superiority in energy-load balancing when the energy efficiency is comparable with that of the MBRP scheme. © 2017 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Electric power transmission networks; Energy conservation; Energy harvesting; Heterogeneous networks; Power management (telecommunication); Radio communication; Coverage probabilities; Heterogeneous cellular networks; Numerical results; Performance analysis; Received power; Renewable energies; Transmit power; User associations; Energy efficiency

Authors: Liu X., Yu X., Li Z., Chang X.
Title: An inductive-capacitive hybrid pulsed power supply for energy recovery
Source title: IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Tsinghua University, Beijing, China
Authors with affiliations: Liu, X., Department of Electrical Engineering, Tsinghua University, Beijing, China; Yu, X., Department of Electrical Engineering, Tsinghua University, Beijing, China; Li, Z., Department of Electrical Engineering, Tsinghua University, Beijing, China; Chang, X., Department of Electrical Engineering, Tsinghua University, Beijing, China
Abstract: The inductive pulsed power supplies for the electromagnetic launchers have one major disadvantage that too much energy is remained and then wasted in the inductors, after the projectile leaves the muzzle. This paper proposes a novel idea to solve this problem. In essence, the solution is a combination and cooperation of the inductive pulsed power supplies and the capacitive pulsed power supplies. The working principle and the theoretical feasibility is discussed and verified through numerical simulations. The simulation results of a 69.2-kJ example system show that 83.5% of the 12.7-kJ residual energy is recovered. And the precharged voltage of the energy storage capacitor in the capacitive unit achieves 109% recovery. © 2017 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Electromagnetic launchers; Energy recovery; Energy storage capacitor; Pulsed power supply; Residual energy; Recovery

Authors: Li L., Wang X., Zou X., Qian D.
Title: Preliminary experiment on shock waves generated by underwater electrical explosion of wires
Source title: IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Tsinghua University, Beijing, 100084, China
Authors with affiliations: Li, L., Department of Electrical Engineering, Tsinghua University, Beijing, 100084, China; Wang, X., Department of Electrical Engineering, Tsinghua University, Beijing, 100084, China; Zou, X., Department of Electrical Engineering, Tsinghua University, Beijing, 100084, China; Qian, D., Department of Electrical Engineering, Tsinghua University, Beijing, 100084, China
Abstract: It is well-known that underwater electrical wire explosion (UEWE) is accompanied by generation of strong shock waves (SSW) with fast front and short duration, which makes it attractive for various scientific and technological purposes. In this paper, a device for UEWE was developed and composed of pulse capacitors (200μF, 16kV), a spark gap switch, and a metal wire immersed in a chamber filled with water. A Rogowski coil and a voltage divider were used for the measurements of the current and the voltage on the wire load, respectively. The shock waves were recorded by a piezoelectric pressure probe (model: PCB138A11). The amplitude of the shock waves was measured to be 82.4MPa at 50mm from the exploding wire. The effects of the experimental parameters (including the wire diameter, the storage energy in capacitors, the energy deposition into the wire) on the shock waves were investigated. It was shown that thicker copper wires would generate stronger shock waves and the amplitude of shock wave was approximately proportional to the energy deposition into the wire. For potential application in oil exploitation, the destruction of the concrete cylinders with a thickness of 75mm by the shock wave was studied. A storage energy of 0.9 kJ is high enough to break the concrete cylinder into pieces. At a position of 75mm from the exploding wire, the shock wave measured in the concrete cylinder attenuates to 43.5% in amplitude of that measured in water without the cylinder. © 2017 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Concretes; Cylinders (shapes); Deposition; Exploding wires; Voltage dividers; Concrete cylinders; Energy depositions; Experimental parameters; Piezoelectric pressure; Spark gap switch; Strong shock waves; Underwater electrical explosions; Underwater electrical wire explosion; Shock waves

Authors: Hou Y., Zhang J., Zhang Z.
Title: The investigation of propylene carbonate based nanofluids as an energy storage medium for pulsed power sources
Source title: IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Taiyuan Satellite Launch Center, National University of Defense Technology, Changsha, China; College of Optoelectronic Science and Engineering, National University of Defense Technology, Changsha, China
Authors with affiliations: Hou, Y., Taiyuan Satellite Launch Center, National University of Defense Technology, Changsha, China; Zhang, J., College of Optoelectronic Science and Engineering, National University of Defense Technology, Changsha, China; Zhang, Z., College of Optoelectronic Science and Engineering, National University of Defense Technology, Changsha, China
Abstract: Propylene carbonate (PC) based nano-fluids containing only 2 ppm TiO2 nano-particles exhibit more than 60% higher impulse breakdown voltage than that of base liquid. It is found that the resistance of the test gap containing nano-fluids increases by double when subjected to high amplitude voltage before the development of electrical breakdown, greatly differing from the invariable resistance in the pure PC case. Besides, compared with pure PC, the streamers in nano-fluids are more complex branched. It implies that the charge carriers in nano-fluids can be effectively captured and scattered by nanoparticles, which is verified by means of thermally stimulated current method. Moreover, the liquid energy band theory and the electro-mechanical force model are employed to explain the electrical process. Based on these experimental results and the theoretical analysis mentioned above, a nano-fluids dielectric coaxial pulse forming line system is developed, and its maximum energy storage density increases to more than 2.5 times higher than that of PC with better operation stabilities. These efforts set a good foundation for the development of a compact pulsed power generator with a new kind of high energy storage medium, and the results show an appealing application of PC based nano-fluids for the future. © 2017 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Nanofluidics; Nanoparticles; Propylene; Titanium dioxide; Compact pulsed power; Electrical breakdown; Energy storage density; Impulse breakdown voltages; Pulse forming lines; Pulsed power sources; Thermally stimulated current methods; TiO2 nano-particles; Energy storage

Authors: Zhang Z., Hou Y., Liu H., Yang H., Zhang J.
Title: Pulse width lengthening technique for compact pulsed power generator
Source title: IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: College of Optoelectronic Science and Engineering, National University of Defense Technology, Changsha, 410073, China
Authors with affiliations: Zhang, Z., College of Optoelectronic Science and Engineering, National University of Defense Technology, Changsha, 410073, China; Hou, Y., College of Optoelectronic Science and Engineering, National University of Defense Technology, Changsha, 410073, China; Liu, H., College of Optoelectronic Science and Engineering, National University of Defense Technology, Changsha, 410073, China; Yang, H., College of Optoelectronic Science and Engineering, National University of Defense Technology, Changsha, 410073, China; Zhang, J., College of Optoelectronic Science and Engineering, National University of Defense Technology, Changsha, 410073, China
Abstract: Recent trends in the further development of pulsed power technology are towards higher power, longer duration and more compact structures. Compact pulsed power generators based on a Tesla transformer, configured using coaxial pulse forming lines, are widely used in the application of pulsed power systems. It is significant to lengthen pulse width of the pulsed power generator. In this paper, the high permittivity liquid dielectric and a spiral structure are adopted to lengthen the pulse width of a compact pulsed power generator. Firstly, the operation principles of the compact pulsed power generator are described. The techniques used to lengthen the pulse width are then presented and analyzed. Prior to its use, the propylene carbonate was purified by filtering to remove particles, de-ionizing, and de-gassing. The high voltage insulation was designed using insulation matching to ensure optimal distribution of the electromagnetic field. Finally, a compact pulsed power generator with longer output pulse duration was developed. For a generator length of 1 m, an output voltage of 100 kV was developed across a 10 Ω resistive load, with a pulse duration of 33 ns. This paper sets the foundations for the future development of compact pulsed power generators using propylene carbonate as an energy storage medium. © 2017 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Dielectric materials; Dielectric properties of liquids; Electric power systems; Electromagnetic fields; Propylene; Compact pulsed power; High voltage insulation; Optimal distributions; Propylene carbonate; Pulse forming lines; Pulsed power systems; Pulsed power technologies; Pulsed-power generators; Pulse generators

Authors: Tahir S., Khaliq A.
Title: Control of grid connected DC-coupled hybrid microgrid
Source title: Proceedings of 2017 International Multi-Topic Conference, INMIC 2017
Affiliations: Electrical and Computer Engineering Department, Center for Advanced Studies in Engineering, Islamabad, Pakistan
Authors with affiliations: Tahir, S., Electrical and Computer Engineering Department, Center for Advanced Studies in Engineering, Islamabad, Pakistan; Khaliq, A., Electrical and Computer Engineering Department, Center for Advanced Studies in Engineering, Islamabad, Pakistan
Abstract: This article presents a Control Strategy for Grid connected DC-coupled hybrid Microgrid. The Microgrid consists of Proton Exchange Membrane Fuel Cell (PEMFC), Photovoltaic System, Battery Energy Storage System (BESS) based on Lead-Acid Battery Technology, along with AC Load and DC Load. The BESS is charged and discharged with a constant current, based on operational constraints of Lead-Acid Batteries. The Voltage of DC Bus is controlled by bidirectional Voltage-sourced Converter. The Control Scheme is tested by variations in DC Load, AC Load and Solar Insolation. Moreover, the rules for operation of PEMFC and BESS in a Grid connected Microgrid, having Time of Use Energy Tariff, are devised and Control Strategy is tested accordingly. All simulations are carried out in MATLAB/SIMULINK environment. © 2017 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Battery Energy Storage System; DC Microgrid; Fuel Cells; Power Management

Authors: Das A., Roy N.K.
Title: Reduction of harmonics distortion and voltage sag of PMSG based wind energy systems connected to distribution networks
Source title: 5th IEEE Region 10 Humanitarian Technology Conference 2017, R10-HTC 2017
Affiliations: Dept. of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Khulna University of Engineering and Technology, Khulna, 9203, Bangladesh
Authors with affiliations: Das, A., Dept. of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Khulna University of Engineering and Technology, Khulna, 9203, Bangladesh; Roy, N.K., Dept. of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Khulna University of Engineering and Technology, Khulna, 9203, Bangladesh
Abstract: Distributed generation based on wind turbine is one of the most growing, effective and potential technologies which has been scattered over the globe. This paper presents a permanent magnet synchronous generator based wind energy system with a static synchronous compensator where an energy storage is incorporated. The combination of battery and capacitor makes this system more efficient in improving its power quality. An AC/DC/AC converter is connected with the system to provide the maximum magnitude of the power to the distribution network; however, it generates harmonics which is a crucial problem. In this paper, the control mechanism of the generator's converter is based on the straight line theory and the pulse width modulation technique is used for designing the voltage source converter of the static synchronous compensator. A proper integration between these control mechanisms creates a stable system. Using PSCAD/EMTDC software, the overall performance of the proposed model is tested on a 12 bus radial network with a non-linear load connected to it. The results obtained from this comprehensive analysis proved that this entire model is successful to eliminate the harmonics, keep the voltage and current within a safe range as well as mitigate the voltage sag. © 2017 IEEE.
Author Keywords: AC/DC/AC converter; Battery energy storage; Distributed generation; Harmonics; Permanent magnet synchronous generator; Static synchronous compensator; Voltage sag

Authors: Hasan S.M., Milon, Hossain M.R., Hossain M.K., Ahmed F., Hossain M.A.
Title: Hexagonal boron cluster as an anode material for divalent-ion (Ca2+) storage: A theoretical study
Source title: 5th IEEE Region 10 Humanitarian Technology Conference 2017, R10-HTC 2017
Affiliations: Department of Physics, Jahangirnagar University, Savar, Dhaka, 1342, Bangladesh
Authors with affiliations: Hasan, S.M., Department of Physics, Jahangirnagar University, Savar, Dhaka, 1342, Bangladesh; Milon, Department of Physics, Jahangirnagar University, Savar, Dhaka, 1342, Bangladesh; Hossain, M.R., Department of Physics, Jahangirnagar University, Savar, Dhaka, 1342, Bangladesh; Hossain, M.K., Department of Physics, Jahangirnagar University, Savar, Dhaka, 1342, Bangladesh; Ahmed, F., Department of Physics, Jahangirnagar University, Savar, Dhaka, 1342, Bangladesh; Hossain, M.A., Department of Physics, Jahangirnagar University, Savar, Dhaka, 1342, Bangladesh
Abstract: There has been always a persistent search for creating cheaper and efficient energy storage devices. After its discovery Li+ ion storage device has become the most preferred choice due to its high energy density. However, an ion storage device that can use Ca2+ ions instead of Li+ ions, will be much cheaper owing to the higher abundance of calcium. Realizing the need for developing novel ion storage devices, present study aims to investigate hexagonal boron (B6) cluster's ability to store divalent Ca2+ ions. The calculated values of adsorption energies show that Ca2+ ions are well adsorbed in B6 cluster and it reaches the maximum storage capacity when two ions are adsorbed into it with bi-pyramidal shape. We have used density functional theory (DFT) for our investigations. Both CaB6 and Ca2B6 have high specific capacities, with theoretical values 826 mAh/g and 1653 mAh/g respectively. Open circuit voltages (OCV) of the CaB6 and Ca2B6 are found to be 3.755 V and 2.993 V respectively. © 2017 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Adsorption energy; B6; Calcium ion storage; DFT; Divalent ion storage; Energy storage device; High specific capacity; OCV

Authors: Ali F., Jiang Y., Khan K.
Title: Feasibility analysis of renewable based hybrid energy system for the remote community in Pakistan
Source title: IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management
Affiliations: College of Economics, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, China; School of Public Affairs, University of Science and Technology of China, Hefei, China
Authors with affiliations: Ali, F., College of Economics, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, China; Jiang, Y., College of Economics, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, China; Khan, K., School of Public Affairs, University of Science and Technology of China, Hefei, China
Abstract: Grid power outage (load shedding) is a common phenomenon in Pakistan, and it is more severe in rural communities where load shedding ranges up to 18 hours a day. The conventional methods of electricity generation are inadequate to meet the load demand. Pakistan is one of the best places in the world from the perspective of solar irradiance. The exploitable estimated potential of wind energy in Pakistan is also quite sufficient, i.e. 132,000 MW. The key objective of the study is to utilize the renewable energy resources and produce electricity at lower cost. In this paper, solar photovoltaic panel (PV) and wind system as energy sources, battery as storage with diesel generator (DG) as a backup for a remote community has been presented. A total of 8 (4 off-grid and 4 grid integrated) alternatives are considered. HOMER software is used for simulation, economic optimization, sensitivity analysis, optimal design, DG running period and the net electricity supplied by the grid. © 2017 IEEE.

Authors: Liu X., Li Z., Wang J.
Title: How many hops are needed in multi-hop energy harvesting wireless networks
Source title: IEEE Vehicular Technology Conference
Affiliations: State Key Lab of ISN, Xidian University, Xi'an, China
Authors with affiliations: Liu, X., State Key Lab of ISN, Xidian University, Xi'an, China; Li, Z., State Key Lab of ISN, Xidian University, Xi'an, China; Wang, J., State Key Lab of ISN, Xidian University, Xi'an, China
Abstract: Energy harvesting gives a promising way to deal with the power constrained problem by harvesting energy from the external environment. In this paper, the multi-hop wireless network is considered where the relays with energy storage equipments are random scattered in several discs. The chosen relay nodes are used to decode-and-forward(DF) the received signals to the next terminal. The other active nodes in the discs harvest energy from the received signal. With the aim to achieve the minimum system outage probability, the close-form expressions are proposed about the optimal disc locations and about the optimal number of hops, respectively. © 2017 IEEE.

Authors: Gastelo-Roque J.A., Morales-Acevedo A.
Title: Design of a photovoltaic system using thermoelectric Peltier cooling for vaccines refrigeration
Source title: 2017 IEEE MIT Undergraduate Research Technology Conference, URTC 2017
Affiliations: Center for Renewable Energies and fight against Climate Change, Universidad Nacional Pedro Ruiz Gallo, Lambayeque, Peru; Departamento de Ingeniería Eléctrica, Centro de Investigación y de Estudios Avanzados, IPN, Ciudad de México, Mexico
Authors with affiliations: Gastelo-Roque, J.A., Center for Renewable Energies and fight against Climate Change, Universidad Nacional Pedro Ruiz Gallo, Lambayeque, Peru; Morales-Acevedo, A., Departamento de Ingeniería Eléctrica, Centro de Investigación y de Estudios Avanzados, IPN, Ciudad de México, Mexico
Abstract: The refrigeration of thermolabile medicines and vaccines require the continuous provision of electrical energy so that their therapeutic efficacy is not affected. This represents an important problem for rural zones where there is no accessible electrical energy. In this work, we design a photovoltaic energy system for refrigeration of thermolabile medicines to be used in rural towns without electrical energy available. The system uses a thermoelectric refrigerator based on the Peltier effect, which produces a temperature difference when electrical power is provided to it. It will be shown that for a typical application for vaccine refrigeration, the required module is about 92 W peak connected to batteries with a storage capacity of 212 Ah. The designed refrigeration system should store 5 l of vaccines at temperatures in the range between 4 °C and 6 °C using a Peltier cell (TEC) that consumes 37 W at 12 V. © 2017 IEEE.

Authors: Dikwatta U., Dias G.
Title: Web archiving for Sri Lanka
Source title: 2017 National Information Technology Conference, NITC 2017
Affiliations: IFS RnD (Pvt) Ltd, Colombo, Sri Lanka; Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, University of Moratuwa, Sri Lanka
Authors with affiliations: Dikwatta, U., IFS RnD (Pvt) Ltd, Colombo, Sri Lanka; Dias, G., Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, University of Moratuwa, Sri Lanka
Abstract: Most websites change from time to time and the previous versions of the sites become unavailable. This is a complication for a user who wants to search for important information which may no longer b e available on the website. This is especially an issue in the case of government websites that contain critical information. The main aim of this research is to archive Sri Lankan websites - in particular government websites - and provide a technique to access these web pages later. Initially, we investigated complications which arise when archiving Sri Lankan sites. Secondly, we built and deployed a system to regularly archive Sri Lankan websites with duplication reduction. We also developed a Joomla component as a server-side archiving mechanism. © 2017 IEEE.

Title: Distributed energy storage operation strategy for retailers based on evolutionary game theory

Abstract: With the increasing proportion of energy storage in the power system, retailers should recommend reasonable operation strategies to their users in order to maximize their profit. In this paper, an evolutionary game model of distributed energy storage operation strategy is proposed, which considers energy storage cost, market price and the degree of market competition. This model helps retailers predict and analyze possible choices of users, and provides reference for further development of the market. © 2017 IEEE.

Authors: Hasan Z., El-Hawary M.E.
Title: Fixed head hydrothermal scheduling incorporating wind energy by Khums optimization algorithm
Source title: 2017 IEEE Electrical Power and Energy Conference, EPEC 2017
Authors with affiliations: Hasan, Z.; El-Hawary, M.E.
Abstract: This paper proposes a new algorithm called Khums Optimization Algorithm (KOA) to solve the fixed head hydrothermal scheduling problem incorporating wind energy (HTSIW) uncertainty. In the hydrothermal scheduling (HT) problem, finding the optimal power allocation of the load among the available thermal unit and hydro units for a period of time aiming to minimize the thermal units total fuel cost. There are many constraints in the HT problem such as real power balance, thermal generation unit power limit constraint and hydro generation unit power limit constraint, water discharge rate, spillage discharge rate, starting storage volume and ending storage volume. In this paper, KOA is used to solve the HTSIW problem for two bench mark systems, then a comparison will be done between the results of both algorithms with other algorithms in literature if possible. © 2017 IEEE.

Authors: Du Y., Wu J., Li S., Long C.
Title: Enhanced distributed MPC design for efficiency utility of autonomous multi-microgrids
Source title: 2017 Asian Control Conference, ASCC 2017
Affiliations: Department of Automation, Key Laboratory of System Control and Information Processing, Ministry of Education, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, 200240, China
Authors with affiliations: Du, Y., Department of Automation, Key Laboratory of System Control and Information Processing, Ministry of Education, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, 200240, China; Wu, J., Department of Automation, Key Laboratory of System Control and Information Processing, Ministry of Education, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, 200240, China; Li, S., Department of Automation, Key Laboratory of System Control and Information Processing, Ministry of Education, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, 200240, China; Long, C., Department of Automation, Key Laboratory of System Control and Information Processing, Ministry of Education, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, 200240, China
Abstract: In this paper, a load management is presented for autonomous multi-microgrids, who consist of multiple Renewable Energy Sources (RESs), energy storages and smart loads. In particular, a new energy mismatch balance and optimal distributed scheduling problem are formulated to achieve the supply-demand match in system-level. By coordinating with each other, the surplus renewable energy among multi-microgrids can be distributed to the corresponding microgrid who requests for extra supply for the loads. Moreover, the enhanced Distributed Model Predictive Control (DMPC) strategy is designed to guarantee the RESs efficiency and necessary demand response. Our simulation results demonstrate the effectiveness of our proposed method. © 2017 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Demand Response; Distributed Model Predictive Control; Load Management; Multi-microgrids; Renewable Energy Sources
Index Keywords: Electric load management; Electric power plant loads; Electromagnetic wave emission; Microgrids; Natural resources; Predictive control systems; Renewable energy resources; Demand response; Distributed Model predictive Control; Distributed MPC; Distributed scheduling problem; Multi micro-grids; Renewable energies; Renewable energy source; Supply-demand; Model predictive control

Authors: Xie W., Xia X.
Title: Distributed energy dispatch of electrical energy storage systems
Source title: 2017 Asian Control Conference, ASCC 2017
Affiliations: Department of Electrical, Electronic and Computer Engineering, University of Pretoria, Pretoria, 0002, South Africa
Authors with affiliations: Xie, W., Department of Electrical, Electronic and Computer Engineering, University of Pretoria, Pretoria, 0002, South Africa; Xia, X., Department of Electrical, Electronic and Computer Engineering, University of Pretoria, Pretoria, 0002, South Africa
Abstract: For multiple electrical energy storage systems (EESSs), the state-of-charge (SoC) balance ensures the maximal power capacity of the group of EESSs, and the supply-demand balance maintains the load operation and reduces energy lost. In this paper, a distributed energy dispatch algorithm is proposed for achieving both the balances of EESSs over an undirected connected communication network. Each EESS shares the information with communication neighbors through the network. The algorithm design contains three parts. Firstly, the sign function is utilized to integrate the charging and discharging models of EESSs into a unified switching form. Secondly, for each EESS, the desired power in system steady state is calculated and containing global coefficients of EESSs, and a distributed observer based algorithm is derived to estimate the desired power, which provides the local power reference for each EESS. Thirdly, for each EESS, based on the local power tracking error and the SoC error between itself and its communication neighbors, the energy dispatch algorithm is constructed by employing the distributed receding horizon control (DRHC) approach. The algorithm realizes the two balances and simultaneously satisfies the power and SoC constraints. Effectiveness of the proposed dispatch algorithm is demonstrated by simulation results. © 2017 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Battery management systems; Energy storage; Algorithm design; Dispatch algorithms; Distributed energies; Electrical energy storage systems; Load operations; Receding horizon control; State of charge; Supply-demand balances; Electric load dispatching

Authors: Kagiri C., Zhang L., Xia X.
Title: Compressor and priority panel optimization for an energy efficient CNG fuelling station
Source title: 2017 Asian Control Conference, ASCC 2017
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Electronics and Computer Engineering, University of Pretoria, Pretoria, 0002, South Africa; Northeastern University, Shenyang, 110004, China
Authors with affiliations: Kagiri, C., Department of Electrical Electronics and Computer Engineering, University of Pretoria, Pretoria, 0002, South Africa; Zhang, L., Department of Electrical Electronics and Computer Engineering, University of Pretoria, Pretoria, 0002, South Africa; Xia, X., Northeastern University, Shenyang, 110004, China
Abstract: Optimized operation of the fast-fill compressed natural gas station(CNG) can result in energy savings in a time-of-use (TOU) electricity tariff regime. The present study seeks to optimize the scheduling of compressor activity for the refill of gas into the cascade storage of a fast-fill station so as to minimize electricity costs where the TOU has been implemented for demand response. The optimized operation of the fast-fill station priority panel in pursuit of minimizing the frequency of compressor on-off action is also presented. The proposed strategy shows possibility to deliver 65.6% savings in energy costs while also minimizing the on-off instances of the compressor which contribute to higher maintenance costs. © 2017 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Compressed natural gas; Costs; Energy efficiency; Gas plants; Demand response; Electricity costs; Electricity tariff; Energy cost; Energy efficient; Maintenance cost; Optimized operations; Time of use; Compressors

Abstract: In order to realize the on-line monitoring of the desalination energy recovery device in the process of operation, a data acquisition and control program is designed to collect, process and control the flow, pressure and rotational speed based on C#. Taking the rapid, stable data transmission and storage security features into consideration, using NI data acquisition card to achieve data transmission and processing, with the MySQL database management system in the background. It has a good human-computer interaction and data convenience and security. This paper introduces the code of the software system what a part of the main function specifically, analyzes and compares the running data of the system. The system has been successfully applied to the desalination energy recovery device of in Daishan and realize the On-line monitoring of the performance and running state of the desalination energy recovery device. © 2017 IEEE.

Abstract: With wind power, photovoltaic and other intermittent new energy for large-scale parallel network, safe and stable operation of the grid is facing great challenges. To develop the energy storage system represented by electric vehicles and carry out flexible load demand side response, and to realize friendly interaction with the large power grid, it will help to cut the peak filling trough and improve the power grid peak and frequency modulation capability. Based on the real-time electricity price of the user, this paper studies the control method of the demand response of the electric vehicle, and maximizes the auxiliary service capability of the electric vehicle while ensuring the battery life and economic benefit. © 2017 IEEE.

Title: Towards a context-driven platform using IoT and big data technologies for energy efficient buildings
Source title: Proceedings of 2017 International Conference of Cloud Computing Technologies and Applications, CloudTech 2017

Abstract: Context-awareness is crucial for leveraging energy-efficient buildings by developing intelligent control approaches in which sensing and actuation tasks are performed according to the contextual changes. This could be done by including the users' actions and behaviours in up-to-date context taking into account the complex interlinked elements, situations, processes, and their dynamics. In this paper, we introduce a holistic platform that integrates recent sensing/actuating and Big data technologies for monitoring and data processing. The main aim is to develop context-driven control approaches whereby energy consumption, production, and storage could be controlled according to actual situations (e.g., occupancy, occupant behaviour patterns, energy production patterns, and weather data). A platform prototype was deployed in our university test site. Experiments have been conducted and preliminary results show the usefulness of this holistic platform for monitoring and data processing in energy efficient buildings. © 2017 IEEE.

Title: Research on TEEN with network coding
Source title: Proceedings of the 2017 IEEE 2nd Information Technology, Networking, Electronic and Automation Control Conference, ITNEC 2017
Affiliations: College of Telecommunication and Information Engineering, NJUPT, Nanjing, China; Jiangsu Provincial Engineering Research Center of Telecommunications and Network Technology, Nanjing, China
Authors with affiliations: Wang, J., College of Telecommunication and Information Engineering, NJUPT, Nanjing, China; Zhang, L., Jiangsu Provincial Engineering Research Center of Telecommunications and Network Technology, Nanjing, China
Abstract: For traditional routing model in wireless sensor networks (WSN), the function of intermediate nodes is storage and forwarding. Due to the limitation of WSN in energy, capability of communication, computing and the capability of storage, it is difficult for nodes to communicate. Existing researches show that using network coding in WSN can enhance throughput and the security transmission of network, and reduce the energy consumption of nodes [1]. This paper chooses a typical TEEN protocol as the research object of network coding. We attempt to employ network coding to achieve the improvement on throughput of WSN and communication performance, and decrease the energy consumption of sensor nodes. Based on these points, this paper proposes to create network coding opportunities on cluster head nodes in TEEN protocol by utilizing the advantages of opposite links, and a new network coding model basing on TEEN (NCTEEN). The results of simulations show that NCTEEN model has better performance than TEEN in terms of throughput and energy consumption. To be specific, the throughput and performance of network are improved and the energy consumption in cluster head nodes is reduced. © 2017 IEEE.

Authors: Fatima H.M., Sajid M.B., Badar A.W.
Title: Design of a combined solar thermal water and space heating system for a commercial building in climatic conditions of Islamabad
Source title: Proceedings - 2017 13th International Conference on Emerging Technologies, ICET2017
Affiliations: U.S.-Pakistan Center for Advanced Studies in Energy (USPCAS-E), National University of Sciences and TechnologyH-12, Pakistan; HITECH University Taxila, Pakistan

Abstract: The purpose of this work is to analyses the potential of solar for space and water heating application in a commercial building in winters. In this research, solar based water and space heating system is designing with the help of TRNSYS software and commercial building is designed on TRNSBuild according to climatic conditions of Islamabad Pakistan. Our designed system has solar flat plat collector, storage tanks, auxiliary heater, divider and pumps. Auxiliary heater is a gasifier which runs with the help of biogas for completing heat demand in cloudy days and for sudden heating requirements. The system is designed for a commercial building with working hours 0900-1700 hrs. In this work, we are analyzing the effect of solar fraction on seasonal and monthly basis with collector area, primary energy saving with the help of collector area and storage size, achieved room temperature after heating, and hot water temperature and its utilization. After analysis of our system we will be able to propose an optimum system with capacity to meet the daily heating requirement of occupants in building. © 2017 IEEE.

Authors: Bo D., Wenzhou L.
Title: Research on control of energy storage by intelligent microgrid for wind/photovoltaic/energy storage
Source title: Proceedings of the 2017 12th IEEE Conference on Industrial Electronics and Applications, ICIEA 2017
Affiliations: Department of Electric and Information Engineering, Changchun Institute of Technology, Changchun, China
Authors with affiliations: Bo, D., Department of Electric and Information Engineering, Changchun Institute of Technology, Changchun, China; Wenzhou, L., Department of Electric and Information Engineering, Changchun Institute of Technology, Changchun, China
Abstract: Thermal power plants operate with coal, which will release huge amount of sulphur dioxide during combustion. This is the symptom for acid rain. It is also one of major composition of particulates enveloping many cities in China. Hence, use of clean energy is imperative. Power generation by green and clean energy from wind energy and solar energy, which are regenerative and pollutant free, will form intelligent microgrid for wind/photovoltaic/energy storage with battery and loads, which can be connected with main power grid as an controllable unit. Control procedures will be plotted based on research on control of batteries for energy storage units of the micro-grid, discussions on way of charging and operation of batteries, analysis of control logic for on/off grid, and value for SOC (state of charge) of batteries as basis for judgment. Interface for host computers should be designed to realize on/off control of microgrid for wind/photovoltaic/energy storage, as well as charging and feeding of batteries, thereby realizing intelligent control for energy storage. This will ensure smooth process of on/off grid while improving efficiency. © 2017 IEEE.

Authors: Hu R., Wang W., Ma W., Wu X., Tang F.
Title: Application of power electronic technology to energy Internet
Source title: Proceedings of the 2017 12th IEEE Conference on Industrial Electronics and Applications, ICIEA 2017
Affiliations: National Active Distribution Network Technology Research Center, Beijing Jiaotong University, Beijing, 100044, China; Collaborative Innovation Center of Electric Vehicles in Beijing, Beijing, 100044, China

Abstract: Energy Internet (EI) is the energy network based on the power system and information architecture. With the access of the renewable energy power generation equipment, energy storage device and various types of power load to power grid, the traditional power system equipment can't meet the diversity of power supply, energy multi-directional flow, active management of power flow and other requirements. How to use the advanced power electronics technology has become the core of the effective control to EI. The state of art of EI at home and abroad is introduced firstly, and the concepts and research progress of EI in different countries are compared in this paper. Then the application status of power electronic technology in EI is introduced. The working principle and function of three important power electronic devices are mainly introduced, which consists of solid state transformer (SST), energy router, and energy switch. Finally, the future development trend of power electronic technology is pointed out based on the analysis of the existing research results at home and abroad. © 2017 IEEE.

Authors: Zhou Y., Wu Q., Yan T.
Title: A hierarchical system for energy consumption monitoring and information management
Source title: Proceedings of the 2017 12th IEEE Conference on Industrial Electronics and Applications, ICIEA 2017
Affiliations: Shenzhen Institutes of Advanced Technology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Shenzhen, China; Department of Electrical Engineering, Hunan University, China
Authors with affiliations: Zhou, Y., Shenzhen Institutes of Advanced Technology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Shenzhen, China; Wu, Q., Shenzhen Institutes of Advanced Technology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Shenzhen, China; Yan, T., Shenzhen Institutes of Advanced Technology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Shenzhen, China, Department of Electrical Engineering, Hunan University, China
Abstract: In this paper, an energy consumption monitoring and information management system based on multi-level energy consumption model is developed. It is based on internet, wireless internet of things and communication technologies of the intelligent terminal such techniques. The system consists of energy usage equipment, monitoring and control layer, network and communication layer, intelligence management layer, analysis and decision-making layer and the end-users layer. Firstly, the swarm load characteristics are studied and multi-level energy consumption model has been built. Then based on the smart terminal measurement system, the whole network is established for measurement, collection, storage, analysis of the user information purpose. The communication between the intelligent terminals and control center can be achieved via the interface of the medium-connection system. So a multi-level energy monitoring and information management platform can be developed in order to master the production consumption dynamics and energy management decision for the management personnel. Based on the practical experiments, the results identified that the system data can be transmitted safely and reliably, and the energy consumption can be regulated scientifically with bright prospect. © 2017 IEEE.

Authors: Tian J., Ren C., Jia Y., Han X., Wang P.
Title: Control strategy of HESS with dual active bridge bidirectional DC/DC converter in DC microgrid
Source title: Proceedings of the 2017 12th IEEE Conference on Industrial Electronics and Applications, ICIEA 2017
Affiliations: Shanxi Key Lab. of Power System Operation and Control, Taiyuan University of Technology, Taiyuan, China; Taiyuan University of Technology, Taiyuan, China; School of EEE Nanyang Technological University, Taiyuan, China
Authors with affiliations: Tian, J., Shanxi Key Lab. of Power System Operation and Control, Taiyuan University of Technology, Taiyuan, China; Ren, C., Shanxi Key Lab. of Power System Operation and Control, Taiyuan University of Technology, Taiyuan, China; Jia, Y., Shanxi Key Lab. of Power System Operation and Control, Taiyuan University of Technology, Taiyuan, China; Han, X., Shanxi Key Lab. of Power System Operation and Control, Taiyuan University of Technology, Taiyuan, China; Wang, P., Taiyuan University of Technology, Taiyuan, China, School of EEE Nanyang Technological University, Taiyuan, China
Abstract: A novel hybrid energy storage system (HESS) is proposed to eliminate the voltage fluctuations in DC microgrid. The HESS is composed of a dual active bridge bidirectional DC/DC converter (DAB-BDC) and a bidirectional buck/boost converter in cascade. In this way, a super capacitor is used to compensate the high frequency voltage fluctuations in the DC bus through the DAB-BDC. The Li-ion battery is used to compensate the low frequency voltage fluctuations through the bidirectional buck/boost converter which works until the super capacitor terminal voltage out of its threshold. The structure of DAB-BDC can provide electrical isolation, and reduce the rated voltage of energy storage devices. Moreover, in the cascaded structure, the HESS can stabilize the DC bus voltage smoothly, and prolong the battery life effectively. The simulation results verified the effectiveness and feasibility of the proposed structure and control strategy. © 2017 IEEE.
Author Keywords: DC microgrid; dual active bridge bidirectional DC/DC converter; hybrid energy storage system

Authors: Bao Q., Cheng Y., Wu Z.
Title: The dynamic impedance modeling and simulation analysis of lithium battery cell in micro power grid
Source title: Proceedings of the 2017 12th IEEE Conference on Industrial Electronics and Applications, ICIEA 2017
Affiliations: Institute of Information Science and Engineering, Wuhan University of Science and Technology, Wuhan, 430080, China
Authors with affiliations: Bao, Q., Institute of Information Science and Engineering, Wuhan University of Science and Technology, Wuhan, 430080, China; Cheng, Y., Institute of Information Science and Engineering, Wuhan University of Science and Technology, Wuhan, 430080, China; Wu, Z., Institute of Information Science and Engineering, Wuhan University of Science and Technology, Wuhan, 430080, China
Abstract: The lithium battery cell model plays a key role in research of high precision micro grid energy storage system. Taking lithium battery cell as the research object, combined with the equivalent circuit method, second-order RC equivalent circuit model which is based on dynamic impedance is established. According to the electric relationship model, SOC is viewed as state variables, OCV-SOC curve is obtained by the HPPC experiment, battery model parameters is identified by using exponential curve fitting based least squares, then get the function relation between parameter values and SOC. Finally, MATLAB/Simulink simulation of the model is used to verify the accuracy of model. Results show that second-order RC equivalent circuit model is of high precision, dynamic impedance can track the change of SOC and accurately reflect the external characteristic of the lithium battery energy storage system, these results are of great significance in micro power grid simulation and research. © 2017 IEEE.

Authors: Zhang H., Ren C., Qin W., Han X., Wang P.
Title: Coordinated control strategy for a DC microgrid with two-level bus voltage
Source title: Proceedings of the 2017 12th IEEE Conference on Industrial Electronics and Applications, ICIEA 2017
Affiliations: College of Electrical and Power Engineering, Taiyuan University of Technology, Taiyuan, China
Authors with affiliations: Zhang, H., College of Electrical and Power Engineering, Taiyuan University of Technology, Taiyuan, China; Ren, C., College of Electrical and Power Engineering, Taiyuan University of Technology, Taiyuan, China; Qin, W., College of Electrical and Power Engineering, Taiyuan University of Technology, Taiyuan, China; Han, X., College of Electrical and Power Engineering, Taiyuan University of Technology, Taiyuan, China; Wang, P., College of Electrical and Power Engineering, Taiyuan University of Technology, Taiyuan, China
Abstract: In order to meet the requirement of different voltage levels of DC loads, the coordination control strategy of a DC microgrid with two-level bus voltage is presented in this paper. The proposed system consists of two DC microgrids with different voltage levels, and the two sub-microgrids are connected through a bidirectional Buck/Boost converter. Hybrid energy storage systems (HESS) together with its control strategy are developed to smooth voltage ripple in the system. According to the droop characteristics of sub-microgrids, a droop control strategy of the bidirectional Buck/Boost converter is designed in detail to keep power balance of the two sub-micrigrids. Moreover, the bus voltage stability can be maintained by the control strategy. Besides, the whole system operation can be optimized and the HESS life can be prolonged. Finally, the availability of the control strategy is verified by experiments. © 2017 IEEE.

Abstract: With the rapid development of new energy industries, the development of energy storage technology is becoming the focus of attention. Energy storage technology as a process operation of the grid in mining, generation, transmission, distribution, use, storage of six links, plays an important role in grid and distributed generation based on micro-grid system; These technology applications will also bring major changes in the traditional power system design, planning, scheduling, control and so on. Current research is mainly used for energy storage technology of distributed photovoltaic power generation, wind power systems; Energy storage converter played an energy storage system, an important part, between the photovoltaic panels, wind turbines and grid played interface role in achieving the two-way exchange of energy. Firstly, this paper describes the development and the classification of the bidirectional energy storage converter, and analyzes the structure and working principle of the bi-directional DC/DC converter and AC/DC converter topology. Then establish the mathematical model of single-phase PWM rectifier circuit is established, which is based on the rotating coordinate transformation, This paper - investigates the bidirectional flow of energy between network side and energy storage battery through selecting different control strategy to operate the system. According to the current inner loop and voltage outer loop control, the system of energy storage can run steadily. © 2017 IEEE.

Authors: Tian Y., Li D., Tian J., Xia B.
Title: An optimal nonlinear observer for state-of-charge estimation of lithium-ion batteries
Source title: Proceedings of the 2017 12th IEEE Conference on Industrial Electronics and Applications, ICIEA 2017
Affiliations: College of Optoelectronic Engineering, Shenzhen University, Shenzhen, China; Graduate School at Shenzhen, Tsinghua University, Shenzhen, China
Authors with affiliations: Tian, Y., College of Optoelectronic Engineering, Shenzhen University, Shenzhen, China; Li, D., College of Optoelectronic Engineering, Shenzhen University, Shenzhen, China; Tian, J., College of Optoelectronic Engineering, Shenzhen University, Shenzhen, China; Xia, B., Graduate School at Shenzhen, Tsinghua University, Shenzhen, China
Abstract: As the soaring development of electric vehicles and distributed generation systems, lithium-ion battery has been commonly used for energy storage. Accurate estimation of state of charge (SOC) is crucial for charging or discharging the batteries safely and reliably. However, the SOC is immeasurable and nonlinearly varies with factors (e.g., current rate, battery degeneration, ambient temperature and measurement noise), a reliable and robust algorithm for SOC estimation is accordingly expected. In this paper, an optimal nonlinear observer (ONLO) for SOC estimation is proposed. The particle swarm optimization algorithm is employed to optimize parameters of the nonlinear observer. The proposed approach is verified by experiments performed on INR18650-25R lithium-ion batteries produced by SAMSUMG SDI. Experimental results indicate that the proposed ONLO can accurately estimate the battery SOC with a mean absolute error of 1.8% and a maximum error of less than 6.5%, which are both lower than that of the unscented Kalman filter (UKF). Furthermore, the computation cost of the ONLO is reduced to 30% compared with the UKF. © 2017 IEEE.
Author Keywords: lithium-ion batteries; optimal nonlinear observer; particle swarm optimization; state of charge

Abstract: The energy storage inverter is the interface between the power grid and the energy storage device, which can be used for different field (grid connected system, isolated island system and hybrid system) with a series of special features. With the development of science and technology, electrical energy in the production of electricity has been provided by a single power supply to the energy storage development. The electric energy storage will greatly facilitate the needs of people, and the power equipment capacity can better utilized to, and reduce the cost of power supply from the side. In the process of energy storage, there is a more critical device-the energy storage inverter, which is the bridge between the energy storage power grid and the energy storage equipment. © 2017 IEEE.

Title: Structual analysis of ball-on-sphere system using bond graph technique
Source title: 2017 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Electro-Technology for National Development, NIGERCON 2017
Affiliations: Faculty of Engineering, Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Ahmadu Bello University, Zaria Kaduna-State, Nigeria

Abstract: This paper presents the novel structural analysis of ball-on-sphere system using bond graph technique. The structural analyses carried out are controllability and observability of the system. To achieve these analyses, the system was modelled using bond graph modelling technique. In the modelling procedures, the various subsystems, storage elements, junction structures, transformer elements with appropriate causality assignments and energy exchange that make up the ball-on-sphere system were identified and modelled. The structural controllability and observability properties of the system were carried out on the developed causal bond graph model of the system based on bond graph rules. From the structural analyses, it was established that the developed model was controllable and observable. © 2017 IEEE.

Title: Polynomial Subset Based Efficient Key Management for Lightweight Devices Networks

Abstract: Wireless Sensor Networks (WSNs) is highly vulnerable to security attacks because of resource-constrained wireless devices. Complex and resource intensive security schemes are infeasible and reduce the network lifetime. We have explored polynomial distribution based key establishment schemes and identified an issue that the resultant polynomial value is either storage intensive or infeasible when large values are multiplied, and it becomes more costly when these polynomials are regenerated dynamically after each node join or leave operations. To reduce the computation overhead on a cluster head, we have proposed XOR based key management scheme. Simulation scenarios are performed using NS 2.35 to validate the results for storage, communication, latency, energy, and polynomial calculation costs. Proposed XOR based calculation reduces 65% computing cost. The reduction of memory overheads is from p-bits to m-bits where m © 2016 IEEE.

Authors: Xie H., Jia G., Han G., Wan J., Ren Y., Huang J., You X.
Title: Hybrid-LRU caching scheme for PDRAM hybrid memory architecture in cloud computing
Source title: Proceedings - 2016 International Conference on Identification, Information and Knowledge in the Internet of Things, IIKI 2016
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science and Technology, Hangzhou Dianzi University, Hangzhou, 310018, China; Key Laboratory of Complex Systems Modeling and Simulation, Ministry of Education, Hangzhou, 310018, China; Department of Information and Communication Systems, Hohai University, Changzhou, 213022, China; School of Information and Electronic Engineering, Zhejiang University of Science and Technology, Hangzhou, 310023, China
Authors with affiliations: Xie, H., Department of Computer Science and Technology, Hangzhou Dianzi University, Hangzhou, 310018, China; Jia, G., Department of Computer Science and Technology, Hangzhou Dianzi University, Hangzhou, 310018, China, Key Laboratory of Complex Systems Modeling and Simulation, Ministry of Education, Hangzhou, 310018, China; Han, G., Department of Information and Communication Systems, Hohai University, Changzhou, 213022, China; Wan, J., School of Information and Electronic Engineering, Zhejiang University of Science and Technology, Hangzhou, 310023, China; Ren, Y., Department of Computer Science and Technology, Hangzhou Dianzi University, Hangzhou, 310018, China; Huang, J., Department of Computer Science and Technology, Hangzhou Dianzi University, Hangzhou, 310018, China; You, X., Department of Computer Science and Technology, Hangzhou Dianzi University, Hangzhou, 310018, China
Abstract: This in recent years, the mixed memory (PDRAM) which is consisted of the phase-change memory (PRAM) and the conventional memory (DRAM) has drawn a lot of attention from both industry and academia. It is a promising alternative to replace the traditional memory architecture. PDRAM has good characteristics as large capacity, good stability and non-volatile, while PRAM has disadvantages of a limited life and large access latency. Traditional policies are not sufficient to be directly applied to the PDRAM memory architecture. They cannot adapt to the new features of the hybrid architecture because of their undifferentiated operation, extensive use of PRAM can cause performance degradation and shorten the life of PDRAM memory. This paper proposed Hybrid-LRU caching scheme to address these problems. Our scheme mainly uses the cache consistency address resolution mode to distinguish between different physical mediums in PDRAM, and then take different actions depending on different physical mediums. We have taken a variety of tradition policies like LRU, FIFO, RANDOM, CFLRU to make experimental comparisons. The experimental results have shown that our scheme can reduce the PRAM utilization rate of 11.8% and improve the performance by 4.6%, energy consumption of write and read operation can be reduced up to 88.2%. © 2016 IEEE.
Author Keywords: cache policy; energy; hybrid memory architecture; performance; phase change memory
Index Keywords: Dynamic random access storage; Energy utilization; Internet of things; Memory architecture; Phase change memory; Conventional memory; energy; Experimental comparison; Hybrid architectures; Hybrid memory architectures; performance; Performance degradation; Phase change memory (pram); Cache memory

Authors: Li W., Zhao Y., Liu Y., Chen M.
Title: SMEFF: A scalable memory extension fabric for FPGA
Source title: 2017 International Conference on Field-Programmable Technology, ICFPT 2017
Affiliations: State Key Laboratory of Computer Architecture, Insitute of Computing Technology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, China
Authors with affiliations: Li, W., State Key Laboratory of Computer Architecture, Insitute of Computing Technology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, China; Zhao, Y., State Key Laboratory of Computer Architecture, Insitute of Computing Technology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, China; Liu, Y., State Key Laboratory of Computer Architecture, Insitute of Computing Technology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, China; Chen, M., State Key Laboratory of Computer Architecture, Insitute of Computing Technology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, China
Abstract: In resource-constrained FPGA systems, off-chip memory plays an important role in both prototype verification and acceleration systems for big data. As the scale of applications become increasingly large and complex, the data to be processed grows exponentially. In contrast, FPGAS provide limited memory capacity and bandwidth, severely limiting the scale and performance of prototype verification systems and acceleration systems. Furthermore, data movement is expected to be a dominant consumer of energy, thus inefficient data movement between different DRAM modules also incurs significant performance and energy penalties. This paper proposes a practical design: A Scalable Memory Extension Fabric for FPGA (SMEFF), which is an asynchronous memory access mechanism and exploits cascaded technology to solve the problem of memory capacity and bandwidth. SMEFF uses two key technologies to achieve memory capacity and bandwidth improvements, and shrink the latency and overhead of data movement-the first is an FPGA-based high-speed serial bus to build a multi-level memory fabric instead of the traditional parallel bus mechanism to solve the signal integrity problem. The second is a module to module (M-To-M) DMA data movement technology, which reduces the latency and overhead of data movement between memory modules. We implement SMEFF on an FPGA-based prototype to demonstrate the feasibility of our approach. Experimental results show that SMEFF provides 5x memory capacity increase and up to 3.6x memory bandwidth improvement compared to state-of-the-art FPGA-based memory systems, and outperforms PCIe-based systems. The data movement of M-TO-M's DMA technology obtains up to 3x latency reduction, and average of 21.1% to 61.1% energy reduction compared to state-of-the-art FPGA-based memory systems. SMEFF thus increases FPGA-based prototype memory systems capacity and bandwidth. More importantly, our architecture provides opportunities for the design of scalable, cost-effective FPGA-based memory subsystems. © 2017 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Bandwidth; Big data; Cost effectiveness; Dynamic random access storage; Field programmable gate arrays (FPGA); Integrated circuit design; System buses; Acceleration systems; High-speed serial bus; Latency reduction; Memory subsystems; Multilevel memory; Prototype verification; Prototype verification systems; Signal-integrity problems; Memory architecture

Abstract: The energy, electrical and thermal assessments are complex audit procedures that are currently regulated by prescriptions, technical rules and international and national guidelines. Such procedures are applied in order to evaluate the energy efficiency of the material and human resource allocations within any enterprise. This paper presents the technical aspects encountered throughout the elaboration of the energy audit for an urban electric transport operator. Methods taken to optimize the working states of the integrated power components and their efficiency are also presented. © 2017 IEEE.

Authors: Liu B., Ruan X., Xia M., Gong Y., Yang J., Ge W., Yang J.
Title: An energy-efficient accelerator for hybrid bit-width DNNs
Source title: 2017 IEEE Symposium Series on Computational Intelligence, SSCI 2017 - Proceedings
Affiliations: National ASIC System Engineering Technology Research Center, Southeast University, Nanjing, 210096, China
Authors with affiliations: Liu, B., National ASIC System Engineering Technology Research Center, Southeast University, Nanjing, 210096, China; Ruan, X., National ASIC System Engineering Technology Research Center, Southeast University, Nanjing, 210096, China; Xia, M., National ASIC System Engineering Technology Research Center, Southeast University, Nanjing, 210096, China; Gong, Y., National ASIC System Engineering Technology Research Center, Southeast University, Nanjing, 210096, China; Yang, J., National ASIC System Engineering Technology Research Center, Southeast University, Nanjing, 210096, China; Ge, W., National ASIC System Engineering Technology Research Center, Southeast University, Nanjing, 210096, China; Yang, J., National ASIC System Engineering Technology Research Center, Southeast University, Nanjing, 210096, China
Abstract: This paper proposed an energy-efficient accelerator for hybrid bit-width DNNs. To speedup the DNNs and make it energy-efficient, we first propose a hybrid bit-width compression method that can save the memory storage of the state-of-the-art network LeNet and AlexNet by 7x and 8x with negligible accuracy loss. Also we propose an energy-efficient iterative logarithmic multiplier with approximate computing to process the multiply-accumulate operations for DNNs. The computational ability and adaptability of the FPGA greatly expands by using the LUT-based multiplier with improved iterative logarithmic rather than a DSP-based multiplier. The accelerator power is reduced from 24.1 W to 14.3 W. The accelerator proposed performs 1.53 times better in power efficiency and can achieve 33.98 GOP/s/W comparing with state-of-the-art architecture. © 2017 IEEE.

Authors: Sun Q., Wang D., Ma D., Huang B.
Title: Multi-objective energy management for we-energy in Energy Internet using reinforcement learning
Source title: 2017 IEEE Symposium Series on Computational Intelligence, SSCI 2017 - Proceedings
Affiliations: School of Information Science and Engineering, Northeastern University, Shenyang, China
Authors with affiliations: Sun, Q., School of Information Science and Engineering, Northeastern University, Shenyang, China; Wang, D., School of Information Science and Engineering, Northeastern University, Shenyang, China; Ma, D., School of Information Science and Engineering, Northeastern University, Shenyang, China; Huang, B., School of Information Science and Engineering, Northeastern University, Shenyang, China
Abstract: We-Energy is a novel energy production-storage-consumption mode proposed for Energy Internet, where more renewable energy can be utilized. This paper mainly focuses on the energy management of We-Energy in Energy Internet consisting of combined heat and power unit (CHP), photovoltaic unit, heating only unit and storage device. To construct an environmental-friendly and low-operating cost energy consumption structure, a multi-objective optimization model is proposed in this paper. Furthermore, in order to satisfy the power and heat demands of the We-Energy simultaneously as well as realizing minimum operating cost and pollutant emission, an intelligent energy management system (IEMS) is presented. In particular, reinforcement learning method has been implemented to formulate the optimal operating strategy. Eligibility trace theory is also been introduced to accelerate the computational process. Finally, simulation results are given to prove the effectiveness of the proposed optimization strategy. © 2017 IEEE.

Authors: Haggag S., Ibrahim G., Katsikogiannis A., Tesh A., Kamal H., Menezes N., Al Nuaimi R.
Title: Experimental study of solar thermal energy storage in sand system
Source title: 4th IEEE International Conference on Engineering Technologies and Applied Sciences, ICETAS 2017
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, School of Engineering, American University in Dubai, Dubai, United Arab Emirates
Authors with affiliations: Haggag, S., Department of Mechanical Engineering, School of Engineering, American University in Dubai, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Ibrahim, G., Department of Mechanical Engineering, School of Engineering, American University in Dubai, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Katsikogiannis, A., Department of Mechanical Engineering, School of Engineering, American University in Dubai, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Tesh, A., Department of Mechanical Engineering, School of Engineering, American University in Dubai, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Kamal, H., Department of Mechanical Engineering, School of Engineering, American University in Dubai, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Menezes, N., Department of Mechanical Engineering, School of Engineering, American University in Dubai, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Al Nuaimi, R., Department of Mechanical Engineering, School of Engineering, American University in Dubai, Dubai, United Arab Emirates
Abstract: The current study aims to investigate the utilization of UAE's desert sand as a medium to store energy in a high-temperature Sensible Thermal Energy Storage System. Sand can provide a unique and eco-friendly alternative to current storage mediums, while having minimized cost and maintenance. Oil will be heated and pumped to flow through pipes leading to the Thermal Energy Storage Element, where the sand will be thermally charged. After the desired temperature in the sand is obtained, the oil is left to cool down while the sand loses some of its stored energy. Finally, the remaining sand energy is discharged and absorbed by the oil, whose heat is utilized to generate electricity using a Peltier Element. To design and manufacture the prototype, in depth research on the thermal properties of UAE's desert sand was conducted. Furthermore, a 3 D model of the prototype is included, along with the details on its operating principle. To determine the efficiency of the system, the experiments conducted are divided into three subsections: Charging Phase, Storing Phase, and Discharging Phase. Certain constraints in designing the system are addressed along with several methods to improve the system's functionality for successful future optimization. The charging time required by the sand to reach 150°C was found experimentally to be 56 minutes. After 5 hours of storing, under insulated conditions, the sand decreased to 91° indicating a storing efficiency of 62.4%. In 7 minutes the oil absorbed back the heat from the sand with a discharge efficiency of 61%, followed by a voltage generation of 0.535 V by the thermoelectric generator. © 2017 IEEE.
