Authors: Zheng S., Niu X.
Title: Design technology and benefits of the three gorges project in China [Technologies de conception et bénéfices de l’aménagement des trois Gorges en Chine]
Source title: 26th International Congress on Large Dams, 2018
Affiliations: CHANGJIANG WATER CONSERVANCY COMMISSION, China; CHANGJIANG INSTITUTE OF SURVEY PLANNING DESIGN AND RESEARCH, China
Authors with affiliations: Zheng, S., CHANGJIANG WATER CONSERVANCY COMMISSION, China; Niu, X., CHANGJIANG INSTITUTE OF SURVEY PLANNING DESIGN AND RESEARCH, China
Abstract: The Three Gorges Project is located on the main stream of the Yangtze River in Sandouping town of Yichang City, Hubei province, China. The drainage basin area of the project is 1 million km 2 , and the development mode of “one stage development, one stage construction, by-stage impoundment and continuous migration” was adopted for the construction of the project. The TGP is a key project for harnessing and developing the Yangtze River basin. Because of the advantageous geographical position and natural conditions, it plays a unique role in flood control, power generation, shipping and other aspects of the Yangtze River management and social-economic development in the basin, and its status is irreplaceable for any other projects. In addition, the construction of the TGP plays an important role in providing water sources, diverting water from the south to the north, developing aquatic products and tourism, improving the environment and promoting the technological development of water conservancy and Hydropower projects. The elevation of dam crest of TGP is 185 m, the normal pool level of the reservoir is 175 m, the flood control level is 145 m, and the flood control capacity under normal pool level is 22.15 billion m 3 . With regulation of the TGP, the flood control standards of Jingjiang River can reach to 100-year return period. When a flood is greater than 100-year period and less than 1000-year period, including the 1870 flood, which is almost the largest in the history, the discharge of Zhicheng (the gauge station in Jingjiang river section) can be reduced to 80,000 m 3 /s. Under the cooperation of Jingjiang and other flood detention basins, the devastating disaster of the dike break at the middle-downstream of Yangtze River can be prevented. The chance and the discharge of diversion using the retention basin nearby can also be greatly reduced. The installed capacity of Three Gorges power station is 18200 MW (including the underground powerhouse it reaches to 22,400 MW), the firm capacity is 4990 MW, and the annual generating capacity is 88.2 billion kWH. The power can replace coal by 4,000 ~ 45 million tons, which can reduce coal pollution and improve the environment. The TGP is equipped with the double-lane five-step ship lock weighing 10,000 tons and a vertical ship lift weighing 3,000 tons, which is an important basic project in Yangtze River shipping network construction. The navigation function has the advantage of saving investment and costs of other means of transportation, promoting the rationalization of social comprehensive traffic structure, promoting the economy resource development and the development of industrial and agricultural in related areas, promoting the optimal allocation of resources and regional traffic balance, and promoting the rapid development of the Yangtze River Economic Belt construction. Construction of the TGP started in 1993. In December 1994, construction of the main project has started and the key project (hydraulic structures) was completed in 2008. Since 2008, the water storage of 175 m scheme has been implemented, and successfully made for 7 consecutive years since 2010. At the present, the project has entered the normal operation stage and is fully displaying the huge comprehensive benefits. The successful use of the innovative technologies of large flood discharge and energy dissipation of high dam, fast concrete construction, large-scale underground cavern design, innovative resettlement programs, and the integrated regulation of multiple-reservoirs together with other reservoirs of Yangtze River, provided strong foundation for the smooth construction of the project, and ensured the comprehensive benefits of the flood control, power generation, shipping and water resources allocation etc. Since the project was put into operation in 2003, it has brought remarkable social-economic benefits to the national development, energy saving and emission reduction. By the end of March 2017, the power generated by TGP is equivalent to saving 3.27 tons of standard coal, reducing carbon dioxide emissions of about 8.58 tons, reducing sulfur dioxide emissions of about 8,990,000 tons, and reducing nitrogen oxide emissions of about 2570,000 tons. The project improved the waterway and water conditions, promoted the development of waterway transportation, and created conditions for the construction of the green ecological corridor of Yangtze River basin. © 2018 ICOLD/CIGB, Paris, France.

Authors: Georg Pikl F.
Title: Pumped storage hydroelectricity in combination with thermal energy storage [Une centrale de pompage-turbinage combinée à des réservoirs d’énergie thermique]
Source title: 26th International Congress on Large Dams, 2018
Affiliations: Graz University of Technology, Institute of Hydraulic Engineering and Water Resources Management, Austria
Authors with affiliations: Georg Pikl, F., Graz University of Technology, Institute of Hydraulic Engineering and Water Resources Management, Austria
Abstract: In a world of energy increasingly dominated by volatile renewable energy generation, energy storage technologies are indispensable for a reliable and sustainable electric and thermal energy provision. With the energy carrier water and its ideal properties and proven storage technologies for electricity as well as thermal energy, it’s possible to cover both energy sectors with demand-based, environmental friendly energy. The groundbreaking idea of a study is the combination of electric and thermal energy storage in one system by the hybrid utilization of the energy carrier water. The unifying part of this innovative 2-in-1 concept is a modified closed loop pumped storage plant. Thus, the heated-up water for thermal energy storage is used for pumped storage operation too. The synergetic application with solar thermal energy enables the transfer of thermal energy from the summer to the winter months with highest demand on thermal heat. The thermal energy is stored and provided by a district heating transmission line, connected with heat exchangers in the dead storage of the pumped storage reservoirs. Using hot water with seasonal fluctuating temperatures for pumped storage plants presents technical challenges for all components of hydropower plants, which can be solved technically. In the study technical solutions for structural components, electric and hydraulic fluid machines have been developed. Besides, also adapted underground power station concepts, power tunnel layouts and reservoir designs have been carried out for efficient thermal energy storage. This innovative concept with the efficient double use of the renewable energy carrier water considerably increases the annual energy turnover and output compared to conventional pumped storage plants. As a consequence, the economic profitability could be improved significantly in comparison with conventional pumped storage plants. Ultimately this environmental-friendly storage concept also reduces construction and infrastructure costs, as well as environmental impacts since the two technologies use the same energy storage infrastructure. With the entire underground realization of such hot water pumped storage plants and its transmission and grid infrastructure also any land consumption is required and a socially acceptable realization is possible. The climate friendly energy storage system with the sustainable utilization of the regenerative energy carrier water should help to save greenhouse gas emissions and further the development of CO2-free energy supply. Last but not least it should improve the economic framework for ecological storage systems by integrating two energy storage sectors in one system at the same time. © 2018 ICOLD/CIGB, Paris, France.
Author Keywords: District heating; Energy storage technologies; Pumped storage hydroelectricity; Renewable energies; Thermal energy storage
Index Keywords: District heating; Electric energy storage; Environmental impact; Environmental technology; Free energy; Gas emissions; Greenhouse gases; Heat storage; Hydraulic machinery; Hydroelectric power; Solar energy; Sustainable development; Thermal energy; Water; Energy storage technologies; Fluctuating temperatures; Pumped Storage; Renewable energies; Renewable energy carrier; Renewable energy generation; Sustainable utilization; Underground power station; Energy efficiency

Authors: Zhao C., Wu X., Huang J., Shi Y., Zhang F., Li H., Kang J., Liu H., Li G., Wang G.
Title: Pengshui hydropower station [Aménagement hydro-électrique de Pengshui]
Source title: 26th International Congress on Large Dams, 2018
Affiliations: Chang Jiang Institute of Survey Planning Design and Research, China
Authors with affiliations: Zhao, C., Chang Jiang Institute of Survey Planning Design and Research, China; Wu, X., Chang Jiang Institute of Survey Planning Design and Research, China; Huang, J., Chang Jiang Institute of Survey Planning Design and Research, China; Shi, Y., Chang Jiang Institute of Survey Planning Design and Research, China; Zhang, F., Chang Jiang Institute of Survey Planning Design and Research, China; Li, H., Chang Jiang Institute of Survey Planning Design and Research, China; Kang, J., Chang Jiang Institute of Survey Planning Design and Research, China; Liu, H., Chang Jiang Institute of Survey Planning Design and Research, China; Li, G., Chang Jiang Institute of Survey Planning Design and Research, China; Wang, G., Chang Jiang Institute of Survey Planning Design and Research, China
Abstract: Pengshui Hydropower Project is one of the cascade hydropower plants developed on the main stream of Wujiang river – a large tributary of Changjiang River. It is developed with multi-functions of power generation, improving navigation and flood control, etc. The power station has a total installed capacity of 1750 MW and provides mean annual electricity of 6.351 billion kW • h. It is a major Load-Frequency control power supplier for the Chongqing Grid. The main buildings of the project consist of an arc-shaped RCC gravity dam, adopting surface outlets for flood discharge with maximum unit-width flow of 335 m 3 /s; a “single-cavern type” underground power station adopting techniques of heat dissipation and anti-condensation etc. to cope with problems introduced from the super long vertical isolated phase enclosed bus, and technology of automatic pressure-adjusting which has resulted into a tailwater tunnel with height-varying ceiling; and navigation structures with a layout of single-stage ship lock  channel + single-stage vertical ship lift”. With the project, the approximate 100 km waterway in the reservoir was canalized where more than 70 dangerous shoals being submerged, which has greatly improved the navigation condition in the reservoir area and promoted the shipping industry and economic development along the reservoir rim, correspondingly. Meanwhile, as the compensating storage for Three Gorges reservoir, Pengshui reservoir can store flood water from Wujiang River to reduce flood risk at the middle and downstream of Changjiang River, in case when catastrophic basin-scale flood occurs. The operation of the reservoir has also upgraded the natural environment, which has boosted local tourism industry and economic development. Moreover, every year, the clean hydro energy provided by the station reduces, equivalently, 2,200,000 tons of coal consumption, emissions of 5,000,000 tons of CO 2 , 17,000 tons of SO 2 and 14,800 tons of CO, 520,000 tons of smoke dust, and 800,000 tons of waste residue. © 2018 ICOLD/CIGB, Paris, France.

Authors: Zhang M.W., Liu S.D., Meng Q.B., Qian D.Y., Zhang N.
Title: Rock energy evolution under triaxial cyclic loading-unloading compression
Source title: Rock Dynamics &amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;ndash; Experiments, Theories and Applications - Proceedings of the 3rd International Conference on Rock Dynamics and Applications, ROCDYN-3 2018
Affiliations: State Key Laboratory for Geomechanics and Deep Underground Engineering, China University of Mining and Technology, Xuzhou, China; School of Mines, China University of Mining and Technology, Xuzhou, China
Authors with affiliations: Zhang, M.W., State Key Laboratory for Geomechanics and Deep Underground Engineering, China University of Mining and Technology, Xuzhou, China; Liu, S.D., State Key Laboratory for Geomechanics and Deep Underground Engineering, China University of Mining and Technology, Xuzhou, China; Meng, Q.B., State Key Laboratory for Geomechanics and Deep Underground Engineering, China University of Mining and Technology, Xuzhou, China; Qian, D.Y., School of Mines, China University of Mining and Technology, Xuzhou, China; Zhang, N., School of Mines, China University of Mining and Technology, Xuzhou, China
Abstract: Triaxial cyclic loading-unloading experiments on red sandstones were carried out under 6 kinds of confining pressures on the MTS 816 test system. Total energy density, elastic energy density and dissipated energy density absorbed by rock specimens under different confining pressures were obtained. Evolution process of energy accumulation and dissipation and confining pressure effect of the distribution law were analyzed, to reveal the energy conversion mechanism from rock deformation to rock failure. The energy conversion equations in different stress-strain stages were established. The results showed with the rise of confining pressure, characteristic energy density of the rock increased in a power—exponent form, and the energy storage limit density of the rock increased faster than the maximum dissipated energy density. The confining pressure increased the intensity of energy input, improved the efficiency of energy accumulation and inhibited the degree of energy release. © 2018 Taylor & Francis Group, London.
Index Keywords: Cyclic loads; Dynamics; Energy conversion; Energy dissipation; Pressure effects; Rock pressure; Unloading; Characteristic energy; Confining pressure effect; Conversion equation; Conversion mechanism; Different confining pressures; Dissipated energy density; Elastic energy density; Energy accumulation; Rocks

Abstract: The proceedings contain 242 papers. The special focus in this conference is on European Rock Mechanics. The topics include: Benefits and limitations of applying directional shear strengths in 2D and 3D limit equilibrium models to predict slope stability in highly anisotropic rock masses; mathematical modelling of limit states for load bearing elements in room-and-pillar mining of saliferous rocks; quantitative risk analysis of fragmental rockfalls: A case study; experimental and numerical investigation the divergence of horizontal and vertical displacement in longwall mining; numerical analysis of the rheological behaviour of the Socompa debris avalanche, Chile; numerical study on the strategies to reduce the risk of induced seismicity in an enhanced geothermal system; the reasons of landslides activization at sakhalin island (On the example of landslide exploration at the river Lazovaya); prediction of rock movements using a finite-discrete element method; simulation of fracture propagation depth and failure in long hole open stoping; the Ural scientific school of Geomechanics: Fundamental and applied research; hydraulically fractured hard rock aquifer for seasonal storage of solar thermal energy; peculiarities of numerical modeling of the conditions for the formation of water inflows into open-pit workings when constructing the protective watertight structures at the Koashvinsky quarry; numerical study of the hydraulic fracturing and energy production of a geothermal well in northern Germany; a mathematical approach for prediction of inclinometer measurements in open-pit coal mine slopes; comparison of limit equilibrium and finite element methods to slope stability estimation; analyzing slope stability in bimrocks by means of a stochastic approach.

Authors: Lv H., Xu J., Zhuang Z., Qin W.
Title: Estimation of lithium-ion battery state of health using stacked residual causal convolution neural network
Source title: Proceedings of International Conference on Computers and Industrial Engineering, CIE
Affiliations: School of Mechanical Engineering Shanghai, Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, China
Authors with affiliations: Lv, H., School of Mechanical Engineering Shanghai, Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, China; Xu, J., School of Mechanical Engineering Shanghai, Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, China; Zhuang, Z., School of Mechanical Engineering Shanghai, Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, China; Qin, W., School of Mechanical Engineering Shanghai, Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, China
Abstract: Lithium batteries, as one of the mainstream energy storage devices, are widely used in real life and industrial fields. The failure of lithium-ion batteries can cause serious inconvenience and huge losses. Therefore, it is of great significance to evaluate the state of health (SOH) of battery for battery management. SOH can provide information about the actual available capacity and aging state of the battery to support making battery control decisions. This paper proposed an improved convolutional neural network with long short-term memory network (LSTM) gate structure and Residual Networks to estimate SOH of the Li-ion battery. LSTM gate structure could be regarded as a filter to effectively remove noise from the battery operational data, while the residual network could improve the overall predictive accuracy. The data used to test the model is provided by NASA laboratory. The experimental results show that the model has more satisfactory adaptability and prediction accuracy than general back propagation neural network (BPNN). © 2018, Curran Associates Inc. All rights reserved.

Authors: Drumea A.
Title: Datalogging embedded module for monitoring current and voltage in solar cells, supercapacitors and rechargeable batteries
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Department of Electronics Technology and Reliability, Politehnica University Bucharest, Romania
Authors with affiliations: Drumea, A., Department of Electronics Technology and Reliability, Politehnica University Bucharest, Romania
Abstract: Energy harvesting represents an important option for supplying modern Internet of Things devices. Usually, a large part of the harvested electric energy must be stored for later use so rechargeable batteries or supercapacitors play an important role in the energy harvesting system and their performance has a great impact on system performance. Analyzing the parameters of these storage devices is the motivation of the presented work - an embedded module that monitors and logs currents and voltages during charging and discharging of supercapacitors and rechargeable batteries. The same module can trace the I-V curve for a solar cell in order to find its maximum power transfer point. The module is based on a high performance microcontroller with integrated communication capabilities and stores the measured data in a flash memory that can be read over the serial interface. The paper presents aspects of designing and implementation as well as different tests performed on several solar cells, NiMH and LiIon rechargeable batteries. © 2018 SPIE.
Author Keywords: Data logging; Energy storage

Authors: Madani S.S., Schaltz E., Kær S.K.
Title: A review of different electric equivalent circuit models and parameter identification methods of lithium-ion batteries
Source title: ECS Transactions
Affiliations: Department of Energy Technology, Aalborg University, Aalborg, DK-9220, Denmark
Authors with affiliations: Madani, S.S., Department of Energy Technology, Aalborg University, Aalborg, DK-9220, Denmark; Schaltz, E., Department of Energy Technology, Aalborg University, Aalborg, DK-9220, Denmark; Kær, S.K., Department of Energy Technology, Aalborg University, Aalborg, DK-9220, Denmark
Abstract: Lithium-ion batteries have many advantages in compare to other conventional batteries. Because of that, they have many applications in different sectors such as portable electronic devices, electric vehicles and other fields. To assure that the operation and performance of lithium-ion batteries are reliable, safe and economic, the approximation of state of charge, cycle life and other parameters for lithium-ion batteries are necessary. Equivalent circuit models are an important tool in the field of research in lithium-ion batteries. Several researchers have suggested a variety of equivalent circuit models. Some of these models are simple whereas some others are complicated. This paper presents a review of different equivalent circuit models and parameters identification methods in lithium-ion batteries for energy storage applications. These models include the internal resistance model, one time constant model, two time constants model, Thévenin model, PNGV (partnership for a new generation of vehicles) model, DP (dual polarization) model, improved PNGV model, tree seeds algorithm, electrochemical impedance spectroscopy method, and Randles' model. © The Electrochemical Society

Title: Fibrous materials prepared by centrifugal force spinning
Source title: ECS Transactions
Affiliations: Department of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Brno University of Technology, Brno, 616 00, Czech Republic
Authors with affiliations: Cech, O., Department of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Brno University of Technology, Brno, 616 00, Czech Republic; Zitnik, P., Department of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Brno University of Technology, Brno, 616 00, Czech Republic; Cudek, P., Department of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Brno University of Technology, Brno, 616 00, Czech Republic; Kazda, T., Department of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Brno University of Technology, Brno, 616 00, Czech Republic; Vanysek, P., Department of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Brno University of Technology, Brno, 616 00, Czech Republic; Kadlec, J., Department of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Brno University of Technology, Brno, 616 00, Czech Republic
Abstract: Centrifugal force spinning is a method of preparation fibrous materials by extrusion of viscous liquid material thru thin orifices or needles of rotating spinneret simply by centrifugal force. Due to basic simplicity of the process, the low amount of process parameters needed to control the fiber production leads to easier and potentially more scalable utilization than conventional electrospinning which can be overcome in the field of deposition rate, material variability and also by the possibility of spinning from melt. This contribution gives examples of fibrous materials prepared by this method at the Department of Electrical and Electronic Technology at Brno University of Technology together with showing the possible utilization of force spun fibers in energy storage. © The Electrochemical Society

Authors: Cech O., Benesova P., Strakova A.F., Kadlec J.
Title: Advancement in aluminium-ion batteries
Source title: ECS Transactions
Affiliations: Department of Electrical and Electronic Technology, Faculty of Electrical Engineering and Communication, Brno University of Technology, Technická 10, Brno, 616 00, Czech Republic; Department of Physical Chemistry, Faculty of Sciences, P. J. afárik University in Košice, Moyzesova 11, Košice, SK-04154, Slovakia; Kadlec, J., Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Defence, Brno, Czech Republic
Abstract: We present an overview of recent developments within aluminium-ion batteries, a problem that has attracted wide attention. In this context, our main motivation consists in the abundant raw materials and good electrochemical performance of newly discovered approaches. The present paper then discusses certain relevant historical highlights as well as the state of the art in applicable cathode materials and electrolytes for the aluminium-ion cell technology. Although the concept of aluminium-ion batteries was introduced in the early 1970s, the initial reference to aluminium as a means of energy storage dates back to the pioneering work of Hulot from 1855; this, however, remained virtually unnoticed for decades. The resurrection of interest in the aluminium ion technology is associated mainly with the utilization of ionic liquids such as electrolytes and the preparation of various graphene-derived electrode materials. © The Electrochemical Society
Index Keywords: Cathodes; Electric batteries; Electrolytes; Ionic liquids; Ions; Cell technology; Electrochemical performance; Electrode material; Ion batteries; State of the art; Aluminum

Authors: Miletić M., Luburić Z., Pavić I., Capuder T., Pandžić H., Andročec I., Marušić A.
Title: A Review of energy storage systems applications
Source title: IET Conference Publications
Affiliations: Faculty of Electrical Engineering and Computing, University of Zagreb, Zagreb, Croatia; Croatian Power Utility - HEP D.d., Zagreb, Croatia; Croatian DSO - HEP ODS, Zagreb, Croatia
Authors with affiliations: Miletić, M., Faculty of Electrical Engineering and Computing, University of Zagreb, Zagreb, Croatia; Luburić, Z., Faculty of Electrical Engineering and Computing, University of Zagreb, Zagreb, Croatia; Pavić, I., Faculty of Electrical Engineering and Computing, University of Zagreb, Zagreb, Croatia; Capuder, T., Faculty of Electrical Engineering and Computing, University of Zagreb, Zagreb, Croatia; Pandžić, H., Faculty of Electrical Engineering and Computing, University of Zagreb, Zagreb, Croatia; Andročec, I., Croatian Power Utility - HEP D.d., Zagreb, Croatia; Marušić, A., Croatian DSO - HEP ODS, Zagreb, Croatia
Abstract: Energy storage systems can be used in a wide range of applications in power system. Some of these applications can be procured as services through market mechanisms, while others can be a part of grid infrastructure or merchant installations. This paper reviews all these applications categorized in three main groups:system-level applications, transmission and distribution grid applications and end-user applications. Energy storage systems could be tailored for a specific usage, but they are usually profitable only when multiple applications are stacked. Applications stacking cannot be achieved for all combinations, especially when these applications are not market services or when storage ownership prevents it, e.g. system operator owned storage. The importance of service stacking and issues of storage ownership are recognized and addressed. © 2018 Institution of Engineering and Technology. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Commerce; Energy conversion; Transmissions; End-user applications; Energy storage systems; Grid infrastructures; Market mechanisms; Multiple applications; System levels; System operator; Transmission and distribution; Energy storage

Authors: Betlem P., Midttømme K., Jochmann M., Senger K., Olaussen S.
Title: Geothermal gradients on Svalbard, Arctic Norway
Source title: 1st EAGE/IGA/DGMK Joint Workshop on Deep Geothermal Energy
Affiliations: University Centre in Svalbard (UNIS), Norway; Christian Michelsen Research AS (CMR), Norway
Authors with affiliations: Betlem, P., University Centre in Svalbard (UNIS), Norway; Midttømme, K., Christian Michelsen Research AS (CMR), Norway; Jochmann, M., University Centre in Svalbard (UNIS), Norway; Senger, K., University Centre in Svalbard (UNIS), Norway; Olaussen, S., University Centre in Svalbard (UNIS), Norway
Abstract: The high Arctic archipelago of Svalbard, Norway, is considering to replace the currently operating coal-fuelled power plants. Besides local fossil energy sources such as coal or shale gas in combination with carbon storage and sequestration, renewable sources such as geothermal energy are being considered as alternatives. A thorough assessment of the geothermal energy alternative relies on precise knowledge of the current heat-flow values. In addition, paleo-temperature gradients, former basin configuration and basin development are of great importance for the evaluation of all of these energy sources. We assessed the lateral distribution of the heat-flow for systematically logged commercial petroleum exploration and research boreholes using numerical models. For the Central Tertiary Basin, models were constrained with multi-physical data sets. Geothermal gradients ranging from 25 to 55 °C/km (33 °C/km on average) have been recorded, and these support the indication of local and regional heat-flows that exceed the global continental average. © 2018 1st EAGE/IGA/DGMK Joint Workshop on Deep Geothermal Energy. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Carbon capture; Coal storage; Digital storage; Heat transfer; Petroleum prospecting; Basin development; Carbon storage and sequestrations; Fossil energy sources; Geothermal gradients; Heat flow value; Lateral distributions; Petroleum exploration; Renewable sources; Geothermal energy

Authors: Wang Q., Liu P., Ke L.
Title: Industrial symbiosis development principles drawn upon from economic geography and reflections of Chinese industrial symbiosis strategy
Source title: Conference Proceedings of the 6th International Symposium on Project Management, ISPM 2018

Authors with affiliations: Wang, Q., China Hubei Key Laboratory for Efficient Utilization and Agglomeration of Metallurgic Mineral Resources, 947 Heping Road, Qingshan District, Wuhan, Hubei, 430081, China; Liu, P., China Hubei Key Laboratory for Efficient Utilization and Agglomeration of Metallurgic Mineral Resources, 947 Heping Road, Qingshan District, Wuhan, Hubei, 430081, China; Ke, L., School of Resource and Environment Engineering, Wuhan University of Science and Technology, 947 Heping Road, Qingshan District, Wuhan, Hubei, 430081, China
Abstract: Policy context has been identified as a key factor affecting the implementation of industrial symbiosis which refers to the collaboration among businesses for exchanging waste resources. This research analyzes Chinese policy context affecting industrial symbiosis development from the perspective of policy target, instruments, and delivery landscape. Generally four problems of Chinese industrial symbiosis policy context are identified: firstly, the lack of incentives for the reduction of landfill potentially reduce businesses’ interests in engaging industrial symbiosis activities; secondly, fiscal incentives (both tax and funding resources) for industrial symbiosis activities; thirdly, there is insufficient SMEs RCR/CE facilitation mechanism for utilizing unwanted materials or energy; finally, there are overlapping policy documents issued by government departments, and the responsibility boundary of their sub-national subordinate departments in promoting local resource efficiency is not clearly defined. It argues the need of drawing upon other countries’ experiences for optimizing policies for industrial symbiosis development. © Conference Proceedings of the 6th International Symposium on Project Management, ISPM 2018. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: China; Industrial symbiosis; Policy context
Index Keywords: Electric energy storage; Project management; China; Economic geography; Fiscal incentives; Government departments; Industrial symbiosis; Optimizing policies; Policy documents; Waste resources; Industrial research

Authors: Breedveld P.C.
Title: Bond-graph-based symbolic conversion of a dae model of a planar multibody system into an ode model
Source title: Simulation Series
Affiliations: Robotics and Mechatronics Group, University of Twente, Faculty of Electrical Engineering, Mathematics and Computer Science, Carré building 3.429, P.O. Box 217, Enschede, 7500 AE, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Breedveld, P.C., Robotics and Mechatronics Group, University of Twente, Faculty of Electrical Engineering, Mathematics and Computer Science, Carré building 3.429, P.O. Box 217, Enschede, 7500 AE, Netherlands
Abstract: This paper describes a bond-graph-inspired technique to transform models of multibody systems represented by a mixed set of differential and algebraic equations (DAE’s) into a model represented by first-order ordinary differential equations (ODE’s) in order to make explicit numerical integration possible. The symbolic manipulation required to obtain the ODE formulation is minimized as the junction structure allows to transform only part(s) of the model separately. The approach also applies to all other models in which differential causality occurs due to internally modulated junction structures, but is applied to (planar) multibody systems as kinematic constraints are the most common sources of this kind of DAE models. It is shown, that the proposed transformation also applies to models where one of the generalized velocities is dictated by a velocity source. The procedures shown have an advantage both with respect to efficiency of model manipulation as well as to educational efficiency. © 2018 Society for Modeling & Simulation International (SCS).
Author Keywords: (co-)energy; (generalized) bond graph; DAE; Hamiltonian; Lagrangian; Multibody system model; Multiport storage; ODE

Authors: Avaritsiotis J.
Title: Solar energy enhanced oil recovery: A case study for Kuwait
Source title: Society of Petroleum Engineers - SPE International Heavy Oil Conference and Exhibition 2018, HOCE 2018
Affiliations: Kuwait College of Science and Technology, Kuwait
Authors with affiliations: Avaritsiotis, J., Kuwait College of Science and Technology, Kuwait
Abstract: This paper investigates the performance of a pilot linear Fresnel steam generator, for Enhanced Oil Recovery (EOR), under the climatic conditions of Kuwait. Simulation results are compared to previously published results from a similar pilot installation in Miraah of Oman which delivers 50 tonnes of steam per day. A desired 7 MWth peak power pilot plant is assumed in this work which will produce 80% quality steam at 110 bar and 300 ° C, matching typical EOR specifications. Simulation performed using System Advisor Model (SAM), developed by NRL, based on historical data of Direct Normal Irradiance (DNI) of Kuwait. Given that the heating and pressurization of the subterranean reservoir typically transpires over a period of many months, EOR process is not sensitive to the timing of steam injection, and thus we can assume no steam injection during the periods with no sun. Linear Fresnel collectors have been assumed, which are like parabolic mirrors. Two more assumptions are worthy of comment. First, the SAM model baseline assumptions included 5% soiling on mirrors and 2% average soiling on the receiver envelope. In a typical EOR application, to maintain steam injection around the clock, solar steam is injected during the day and steam produced by natural gas is injected at night. If the rate of steam injection is held constant, gas consumption is reduced by up to 25%. By injecting more steam during the day and less at night, gas consumption can be reduced up to 80% without the need for costly thermal storage; the reservoir itself acts as a primary thermal storage medium. The simulation shows that a peak power of 7 MWth can be achieved with an average output of more than 50 tons of steam per month from May to August and 10 tons/month for the rest of the year; a total of 517 ton/year. The simulated system requires a total land area of 5.2 acres and can eliminate 44,698 ton of CO2 emission per year. To the best of our knowledge, a few studies have been published for Kuwait, which is pursuing a national objective to produce 4 million b/d of oil by the year 2020. This target may be achieved sustainably with heavy oil development using various techniques like unheated-water flooding, hot water flooding, steam flooding, and cyclic steam stimulation. The objective of this study is to investigate the later technique under the local climatic conditions. Copyright 2018, Society of Petroleum Engineers.
Index Keywords: Crude oil; Digital storage; Floods; Heat storage; Heavy oil production; Mirrors; Natural gasoline plants; Oil well flooding; Pilot plants; Solar energy; Steam; Steam generators; Thermal oil recovery; Base-line assumptions; Climatic conditions; Cyclic steam stimulations; Direct normal irradiances; Enhanced oil recovery; Hot water flooding; Linear Fresnel collectors (LFC); Parabolic mirrors; Oil well flooding

Authors: Rahman M.H., Al Joker A.S.
Title: Organizational learning from service innovation in the public sector of Dubai
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Intellectual Capital, Knowledge Management and Organisational Learning, ICICKM
Affiliations: Mohammed bin Rashid School of Government, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Prime Minister's Office, Government of Dubai, United Arab Emirates
Authors with affiliations: Rahman, M.H., Mohammed bin Rashid School of Government, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Al Joker, A.S., Prime Minister's Office, Government of Dubai, United Arab Emirates
Abstract: The main aim of this research is to examine how a public sector organization in Dubai, the UAE (the name of the organization remains anonymous throughout the paper) has gained new organizational learning from its innovation-based service delivery drives in recent years. After exploring the concepts of organizational learning and citizen-centric service innovation, the paper reviews organizational learning vis-à-vis the recently-adopted service quality improvement strategies through customer input in the study organization. The focus of the public services in this study is primarily on energy and water sector. This case is presented in the context of Dubai's rapid transformation from e-Government to smart government that started in 2013. The study attempted to explain how the study organization has been pursuing strategies to involve citizens and clients in designing and planning a more demand-driven service improvement initiative as part of the smart government agenda and what organizational lessons the entity has drawn from the inititive so far. This paper also intends to draw possible policy and strategic learnings that may improve the current practices in engaging the stakeholders - including citizens and business customers - in service innovation in the federal and local governments of the country. This research was conducted using mainly a qualitative case study approach. Secondary sources of information were gathered to develop a deeper understanding of the perspectives of relevant concepts, theories, practices and approaches in citizen centricity, innovation, and service improvement. The study was completed by gathering data through semi-structured in-depth interviews with the entity's key officials to analyse the conditions, challenges and organizational learning from its citizen-centric public service innovation strategies and programmes. The policy implications of this study is that it represents a learning organization on service innovation on the landscape of the UAE's public sector. © 2018 Academic Conferences and Publishing International Limited. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Citizen participation; Organizational learning; Service innovation; Stakeholders

Authors: Liu Y., Zhuge X., Wang Z., Huang B., Le X.
Title: Case study on fluorocarbons interior coating for anticorrosion and wax-deposition inhibition in ASP flooding production
Source title: Proceedings - SPE Annual Technical Conference and Exhibition
Affiliations: Northeast Petroleum University, China; Daqing Oilfield Company Limited, China
Authors with affiliations: Liu, Y., Northeast Petroleum University, China; Zhuge, X., Northeast Petroleum University, China; Wang, Z., Northeast Petroleum University, China; Huang, B., Northeast Petroleum University, China; Le, X., Daqing Oilfield Company Limited, China
Abstract: Under the hovering background of low oil price, alkali/surfactant/polymer (ASP) flooding technique is proven to be vitally important for enhance oil recovery (EOR) in oil industry. The production practice in Daqing Oilfield (China) shows that the EOR of ASP flooding is more than 10% original oil in place (OOIP) over conventional polymer flooding. However, the problems of corrosion and scaling that surface facilities and pipelines encounter with still remain very challenging in ASP flooding production, especially in the strong alkali (NaOH) ASP flooding fields. In the industrialized-application of ASP flooding process, these problems are drawing more and more attention. The corrosion behaviors of surface facilities and pipelines that utilized in strong alkali (NaOH) and weak alkali (Na2CO3) ASP flooding fields were characterized with the integration of production practice, the general anticorrosion measures and the failure of internal coating in fields were presented and demonstrated. A coating solution for fluorocarbons surface treatment was proposed and tested in this case study. The performance of interior surface coatings including corrosion-scaling resistance, wax-deposition inhibition and drag reduction was evaluated with the existence of ASP chemicals in produced emulsions, and the mechanism was discussed from both film-forming and reducing surface energy aspect. The distinct competitive advantage of fluorocarbons interior coating for anticorrosion and wax-deposition inhibition in ASP flooding production was presented. Considerable corrosion and scaling were created and covering the surface facilities such as the storage tanks of ASP chemicals, the pipelines for injection and production, and the heating furnaces in ASP flooding production. Both of the applied physical and chemical protection measures are facing to the challenges of service life, potential environmental threats and unpredictable cost-effectiveness. High bond energy and strong chemistry inertia of fluorinated resins can prevent the coating structure from being destroyed and develop flexibility and weatherability of the coating. The pore resistance and shielding performance of fluorocarbon coating in corrosion environment highlighted actually result from the superior mechanical properties, super-hydrophobicity, and self-cleaning performance. Furthermore, the low surface energy and low coefficient of friction of the fluorocarbon interior coating provide the possibility of pipeline wax-deposition inhibition and drag reduction. The maximum wax-deposition inhibition rate and the maximum drag reduction rate reached 46.42% and 60.00% respectively for high-viscosity ASP flooding produced emulsions in this case study. The reasonable coating configurations and process are certainly indispensable in the potential applications of fluorocarbons surface technology. The case study contributes to the existing knowledge in the implementation of chemical EOR project for a green oilfield development, and it is also helpful to accelerate industrialized-application of ASP flooding and design another emerging pattern-flood pilot. © Copyright 2018, Society of Petroleum Engineers.

Authors: Hong L., Zhang J., Liu L.-W., Qu J.-L.
Title: Low-energy IR780 nanoemulsion for photodynamic therapy
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Key Laboratory of Optoelectronic Devices and Systems of Ministry of Education and Guangdong Province, College of Optoelectronic Engineering, Shenzhen University, Shenzhen, 518060, China
Authors with affiliations: Hong, L., Key Laboratory of Optoelectronic Devices and Systems of Ministry of Education and Guangdong Province, College of Optoelectronic Engineering, Shenzhen University, Shenzhen, 518060, China; Zhang, J., Key Laboratory of Optoelectronic Devices and Systems of Ministry of Education and Guangdong Province, College of Optoelectronic Engineering, Shenzhen University, Shenzhen, 518060, China; Liu, L.-W., Key Laboratory of Optoelectronic Devices and Systems of Ministry of Education and Guangdong Province, College of Optoelectronic Engineering, Shenzhen University, Shenzhen, 518060, China; Qu, J.-L., Key Laboratory of Optoelectronic Devices and Systems of Ministry of Education and Guangdong Province, College of Optoelectronic Engineering, Shenzhen University, Shenzhen, 518060, China
Abstract: As a near-infrared photosensitizer, IR780 is a promising agent for photodynamic therapy. However, its clinical application was limited by its poor aqueous solubility and chemical stability. Therefore, the purpose of this study was to prepare IR780 encapsulated nanoemulsion (IR780-NE) to enhance the solubility and chemical stability of IR780, using a low-energy emulsion inversion point (EIP) method, which could avoid complex procedure and IR780 degradation during preparation process. The IR780-NE presented a homogeneous and clear appearance, as well as a mean droplet diameter of 38.17 ± 3.59 nm, as determined by dynamic light scattering. The IR780-NE greatly enhanced the chemical stability of IR780, with more than 80% IR780 retained after storage at 25 °C for 4 days. The IR780-NE also showed satisfactory physical stability, with no alteration of mean droplet diameter during storage at 25 °C for 4 days or 4 °C for 30 days. The zeta potential of the IR780-NE was nearly zero (-0.27 ± 2.06 mV), and the ultraviolet-visible light absorption spectrum showed that the near-infrared light absorbing ability of IR780 was not influenced. In conclusion, the IR780-NE is a potential delivery system for the application of IR780 in biological systems. © 2018 SPIE.
Author Keywords: IR780; low-energy method; nanoemulsion; photodynamic therapy; stability

Title: Reflectance controlling based on surface plasmon polaritons stimulated over the surface of metallic nanostructures

Wang, H., Wuhan National Laboratory for Optoelectronics, Huazhong University of Science and Technology, Wuhan, 430074, China; Xie, C., Wuhan National Laboratory for Optoelectronics, Huazhong University of Science and Technology, Wuhan, 430074, China
Abstract: The surface plasmon polaritons (SPPs) is an electromagnetic wave that can be stimulated and then propagates over the surface of the preshaped metallic nanostructures or the interface between the surface of the metallic nanostructures and the substrate media due to a strong coupling of incident light and the surface free-electrons moving on the metallic nanostructure surface with a featured micrometer scale. As shown, through SPPs, incident light energy can be localized effectively in a sub-wavelength region or space, and thus so-called light diffraction limit can be break through easily. Therefore, it has demonstrated a good prospects for developing advanced functioned materials or devices such as light absorbing materials, optical antennas, and optical information storage modules. In this paper, we propose a special metallic nanostructures, which can be used to absorb a certain band of incident light by converting them into a kind of local freeelectron oscillation, which means that SPPs can be generated and processed efficiently. As shown, the metallic nanostructures will present a lower reflectivity in the wavelength range, and through adjusting several key parameters such as the period of the metallic nanostructures, we can achieve an effective control of reflectivity because a valley of the reflectivity curve can be formed, which means a low reflectance at a specific wavelength band has been obtained. © 2018 SPIE.

Title: La-Ni based alloys preparation for hydrogen storage
Source title: METAL 2018 - 27th International Conference on Metallurgy and Materials, Conference Proceedings
Affiliations: VSB - Technical University of Ostrava, ENET Centre - Research Centre of Energy Units for Utilization of Non Traditional Energy Sources, Ostrava, Czech Republic; VSB - Technical University of Ostrava, Institute of Environmental Technology, Czech Republic

Abstract: One of the alternative and topical ways of intermetallic and nonferrous materials application is a metal hydrides formation. Metal hydrides allow storage of hydrogen; carry out gas purification and compression. Development of powder metallurgy provides new possibility for investigations in the field of alternative way of hydrogen storage. Solid form of hydrogen storage with the possibility of reversible sorption, gives opportunity for creation autonomous energy storage systems and use hydrogen like a modern energy carrier. Lanthanum-nickel based alloys allow hydrogen storing at ambient temperatures and pressure not higher than 15 bar, which makes the application of these alloys quite practical. The disadvantages of these alloys are the high cost of the initial powdered pure metals and the relatively low mass content of hydrogen in the final alloy. Despite this, La-NI alloys are quite interesting and prospects for further study and modifications. © 2018 TANGER Ltd., Ostrava.

Authors: Liu S., Zhang X., Zhang Y., Liu C., Lu Q.
Title: Holographic model on the mechanism of memory encoding, storage, and retrieval in the brain
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Department of Physics, College of Physical Science and Technology, Xiamen University, Xiamen, 361005, China; State Key Laboratory of Physical Chemistry of Solid Surfaces, Department of Chemistry, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Xiamen University, Xiamen, 361005, China
Authors with affiliations: Liu, S., Department of Physics, College of Physical Science and Technology, Xiamen University, Xiamen, 361005, China; Zhang, X., Department of Physics, College of Physical Science and Technology, Xiamen University, Xiamen, 361005, China; Zhang, Y., Department of Physics, College of Physical Science and Technology, Xiamen University, Xiamen, 361005, China; Liu, C., State Key Laboratory of Physical Chemistry of Solid Surfaces, Department of Chemistry, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Xiamen University, Xiamen, 361005, China; Lu, Q., Department of Physics, College of Physical Science and Technology, Xiamen University, Xiamen, 361005, China
Abstract: Since it was discovered that hippocampus plays a vital role in human memory, enormous investigations on brain memory have been carried out in the last a few decades. However, so far, there has been no report demonstrating how and in what form that the memory is encoded, stored and retrieved. In this paper, we propose a holographic model with theoretical analysis to describe the mechanism of memory encoding, storage and retrieval in brain. The model suggests that memory encoding in brain is achieved through the process of hologram generation in synapses via the interference of the signal wave carrying the outside information and the energy wave emitted by neurons of hippocampus. The holograms are formed by modulated synapses with the structures of the interference patterns. In memory retrieval process, hippocampus emits the same energy wave as that used for encoding with consciousness to induce the reconstruction of the signal wave from the hologram. Experiment was carried out to simulate hologram encoding and retrieval. The discussion presented in the paper shows that the proposed model can reasonably explain some phenomena related to brain memory. © 2018 SPIE.
Author Keywords: Energy wave; Hippocampus; Hologram; Memory encoding; Memory retrieval; Neuron; Synapse

Authors: Ostrý M., Bantová S., Charvát P., Klimeš L.
Title: Corrosion tests on metal - Phase change material pairs used for thermal energy storage
Source title: METAL 2018 - 27th International Conference on Metallurgy and Materials, Conference Proceedings
Affiliations: University of Technology, Faculty of Civil Engineering, Brno, Czech Republic
Authors with affiliations: Ostrý, M., University of Technology, Faculty of Civil Engineering, Brno, Czech Republic; Bantová, S., University of Technology, Faculty of Civil Engineering, Brno, Czech Republic; Charvát, P., University of Technology, Faculty of Civil Engineering, Brno, Czech Republic; Klimeš, L., University of Technology, Faculty of Civil Engineering, Brno, Czech Republic
Abstract: Phase change materials (PCMs) are now a well-established category of materials for thermal energy storage. Most PCMs need to be hermetically sealed in a container or a storage tank because of the risk of leakage to the surrounding environment when a PCM is in the liquid state. A good compatibility between the PCMs and the materials for their encapsulation is very important for the long lifespan and safety of the heat storage systems. Metals are excellent heat conductors and for this reason they are often used as encapsulation materials for PCMs. The present paper focuses on the methodology and results of the compatibility tests of organic and inorganic PCMs with metals. Three sets of metallic samples of encapsulation materials have been prepared. The first set contained copper samples, the second aluminum samples and the third stainless steel samples. The samples were immersed in the PCMs creating metal - PCM pairs and then subjected to periodical heating and cooling in a small environmental chamber, which imitated the operation of thermal energy storage. One set of metal samples was withdrawn for testing each month. The results indicate a good compatibility between stainless steel and all tested PCMs. © 2018 TANGER Ltd., Ostrava.
Author Keywords: Corrosion; Material compatibility; Metals; Phase change materials

The topics discussed include: achieving higher energy in lithium-ion battery cathodes; atomic-scale insights into the ion conduction in solid electrolytes and at their interfaces; rational design and experimental validation of battery cathode materials; enabling high-energy, high-voltage lithium-ion cells: standardization of coin cell assembly, electrochemical testing, and evaluation of full cells; stabilized porphyrins as a new class of ultrafast storage materials with high capacity; enabling next generation batteries through high performance computing; thermal propagation testing within EV battery packs; safety guidelines and changes - lithium batteries: risks in aviation; regulatory updates for li-ion batteries small format and a look at power banks; and the challenges of shipping damaged lithium batteries - understanding the transport regulations to facilitate forensic analysis and product recalls.

Authors: Szeredi I.
Title: Pump-turbine four-quadrant characteristics model for analysis of transient operation
Source title: 13th International Conference on Pressure Surges
Affiliations: Technical Sciences, MVM (Hungarian Power Companies), Hungary
Authors with affiliations: Szeredi, I., Technical Sciences, MVM (Hungarian Power Companies), Hungary
Abstract: It is widely recognised; increasing flexibility is the key for reliable operation of future power systems. The flexibility is the ability of power systems to maintain continuous operation in the face of large and rapid swings in supply or in demand. Recently the most proven and from economical point most efficient technology available for large-scale energy storage is the hydroelectric pumped storage. In the analysis of hydrodynamic transient operating conditions, the most complex boundary condition is the pump turbine. The pump turbine can operate either as a pump or as a turbine depending on the direction of rotation. Performance curves for pump-turbine systems describe the machine characteristics (flow, head, torque and rotational speed) in each of the four quadrants. This paper demonstrates that pump-turbine hydraulic characteristics can be modelled by a numerical tool, easy to use in computations. The use of feature curves helps to exclude singularities in the range of low opening guide vanes and eliminate the instability of the conventional interpolation processes. © 2018 BHR Group.
Index Keywords: Hydraulic machinery; Hydraulic motors; Pumped storage power plants; Pumps; Transient analysis; Characteristics models; Continuous operation; Direction of rotation; Efficient technology; Performance curve; Reliable operation; Transient operating condition; Transient operation; Hydraulic turbines

Authors: Badea G., Oprea C., Felseghi R.-A., Aşchilean I., Bolboacă A.
Title: A review on romanian potential of renewable energy sources for power generation in building applications
Source title: International Multidisciplinary Scientific GeoConference Surveying Geology and Mining Ecology Management, SGEM
Affiliations: Building Services Engineering Department, Technical University of Cluj-Napoca, Romania; SC AIB Consulting SRL, Romania; SC ACI Cluj SA, Romania
Authors with affiliations: Badea, G., Building Services Engineering Department, Technical University of Cluj-Napoca, Romania; Oprea, C., Building Services Engineering Department, Technical University of Cluj-Napoca, Romania; Felseghi, R.-A., SC AIB Consulting SRL, Romania; Aşchilean, I., SC ACI Cluj SA, Romania; Bolboacă, A., Building Services Engineering Department, Technical University of Cluj-Napoca, Romania
Abstract: Unconventional energy sources have gained and will continue to gain a growing share of energy systems around the world, both because of the research effort and the political will involved in their development, and because of the price increase of energy obtained through traditional methods. In order to take advantage of the opportunities offered by the international energy transition process, Romania must undertake new directions for development in the energy sector. Conventional energy sources based on oil, coal and natural gas have had tremendous effects on economic progress, but in the same time proved to be harmful to the environment and quality of life. With the recent remarkable development of sustainable energy technologies and the need to produce it with low greenhouse gas emissions, the use of renewable energy has promising prospects for the energy sector. Energy demand for buildings accounts for 40% of total EU energy consumption, and it is obvious that reducing energy consumption and using renewable energy in the buildings sector is an important part of the measures needed to reduce energy dependency. Romania has a considerable potential for renewable energy resources and is currently very poorly exploited. Renewable energy sources such as solar energy, wind, biomass, hydropower and geothermal energy can play an important role in streamlining and decarbonising power generation systems in stationary applications. This paper presents a comprehensive review of the local availability of renewable energy sources that can provide sustainable energy services for buildings. In addition, renewable energy conversion technologies, including energy storage solutions, and various types of hybrid power systems have been shown schematically. Also, a brief overview of the carbon footprint obtained by the production of a 1 kWh of electricity, which registered in 2017 decreases by 24,75% compared to 2010 due to the increase of the share of renewable energy sources in the mix energy. © 2018, International Multidisciplinary Scientific Geoconference. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Building; Green energy; Hybrid system; Power generation; Renewable sources
Index Keywords: Buildings; Carbon footprint; Coal industry; Electric energy storage; Energy conservation; Energy policy; Energy utilization; Gas emissions; Greenhouse gases; Hybrid systems; Natural gasoline plants; Petroleum prospecting; Power generation; Solar energy; Solar power generation; Conventional energy sources; Green energy; Power generation systems; Reducing energy consumption; Renewable sources; Stationary applications; Sustainable energy technology; Use of renewable energies; Geothermal energy

Authors: Foidas I., Stefanescu D.-P.
Title: Injection pressure – optimization factor for the ugs performances developed in depleted fields
Source title: International Multidisciplinary Scientific GeoConference Surveying Geology and Mining Ecology Management, SGEM
Affiliations: Lucian Blaga University of Sibiu and SNGN ROMGAZ SA, Romania
Authors with affiliations: Foidas, I., Lucian Blaga University of Sibiu and SNGN ROMGAZ SA, Romania; Stefanescu, D.-P., Lucian Blaga University of Sibiu and SNGN ROMGAZ SA, Romania
Abstract: One of the natural gas advantages, as primary energy source, is the opportunity to store it in large volumes under the same state as it is used by the final customers, without being subject to any state modification or conversion in another energy type. Gas depleted reservoirs are the first candidates for turning into underground storages, as the storage process is closest to the production process, but also due to the availability of a large amount of data which makes the reservoir to be well defined and also due to the existing surface facilities that are required for storage operation. The injected gas volume over the gas resource that exists in the reservoir at the beginning of storage development (working gas), has to correspond to the gas demand that has to be covered by such storage. Considering the demand and opportunity for increase of gas storage withdrawal capacity and working volume, the operation of UGSs at highest possible pressure could be one of the safest and most cost-efficient way to achieve such demand. In Romania gas storages usually operate at lower pressures than the original reservoir pressure, while in other countries there are underground storages operating at pressures at least equal to the original reservoir pressure, proving higher benefits. Given this background the paper makes recommendations on the selection of minimum and maximum pressures for UGS operation and analyses the impact of increased injection pressure on the operation of gas storage in Romania. © SGEM2018.
Author Keywords: Depleted reservoir; Initial reservoir pressure; Maximum operation pressure; Working gas
Index Keywords: Digital storage; Energy resources; Natural gasoline plants; Depleted reservoirs; Injection pressures; Operation pressure; Optimization factors; Primary energy source; Reservoir pressures; Underground storage; Working gas; Underground gas storage

Authors: Cuculici R., Oprea C.-R., Vijulie I., Manea G., Săndulache I.
Title: Fractal geometry applied in computer graphics modelling for assessing forest plant systems from the motru-rovinari coal basin
Source title: International Multidisciplinary Scientific GeoConference Surveying Geology and Mining Ecology Management, SGEM
Affiliations: University of Bucharest, Romania
Authors with affiliations: Cuculici, R., University of Bucharest, Romania; Oprea, C.-R., University of Bucharest, Romania; Vijulie, I., University of Bucharest, Romania; Manea, G., University of Bucharest, Romania; Săndulache, I., University of Bucharest, Romania
Abstract: The Motru-Rovinari coal basin is placed in South-West Development Region on an area of about 522.54 km2 and is part of Oltenia mining region. Since the 50-60’s (1955-1960) it was opened here the open cast mining from which was extracted lignite, a quality charcoal. There followed the years of communism when were opened many fronts of exploitation and now has over 50 quarries, micro quarries, dumps and mining extraction. Opening and exploiting the high capacity of coal in this extractions unit, needed to find solutions for the storage of residual material (tailings) have required that large areas of land to set aside from the agricultural, forestry or construction circuit, all with negative impact on the environment. Of these, the deforestation had the biggest impact and on them acted most aggressive in this process of expanding coal mining pits. This work wants to propose a methodology to assess and quantify the forestry systems from an area strong anthropized by mining activities: the Motru-Rovinari coal basin. This way will be noticed and inventory the wooded areas or destroyed using fractal geometry in graphic modelling by determining two indicators: the fractal dimension (FD) and Fractal Spectrum (FS). Comparing with this methodology will be used other techniques and data from remote sensing and GIS, applying the NDVI analysis in estimation of changes at vegetation level, by choosing the supervised classification algorithm to provide both spatial and numerical results on assessments. In this study will be used information provided by sets of Landsat satellite images, from August 1980 to April 2015. We are looking to determine the best methods for monitoring the impact of mining activities over the environment, mainly on forest systems to signal possible unbalances and prevent natural hazards. In the context of the economic policies of the last 50 years, both locally and nationally, focus was placed on discover and exploit new energy resources, without always find mining methods and processes with the minimal impact the environment. Such human activities have become the main factor in generating environmental changes, and between this, the surface mining is one of the most destructive activities that take place on the earth surface. © SGEM2018.
Author Keywords: Forest plant systems; Fractal geometry; GIS; Motru-Rovinari coal basin; Surface mining
Index Keywords: Agricultural robots; Charcoal; Coal; Coal storage; Computer graphics; Deforestation; Digital storage; Energy policy; Fractal dimension; Geographic information systems; Mining; Open pit mining; Quarries; Remote sensing; Satellite imagery; Timber; Coal basins; Environmental change; Fractal geometry; Impact on the environment; LANDSAT satellite images; Plant systems; Remote sensing and GIS; Supervised classification; Coal industry

Authors: Mihaescu L., Lazaroiu G., Pisa I., Ciupageanu D.-A., Berbece V.
Title: Energy valorization of poultry manure through products resulted in a pyrolysis process
Source title: International Multidisciplinary Scientific GeoConference Surveying Geology and Mining Ecology Management, SGEM
Affiliations: University Politehnica of Bucharest, Bucharest, Romania
Authors with affiliations: Mihaescu, L., University Politehnica of Bucharest, Bucharest, Romania; Lazaroiu, G., University Politehnica of Bucharest, Bucharest, Romania; Pisa, I., University Politehnica of Bucharest, Bucharest, Romania; Ciupageanu, D.-A., University Politehnica of Bucharest, Bucharest, Romania; Berbece, V., University Politehnica of Bucharest, Bucharest, Romania
Abstract: This paper addresses the possibility of using poultry manure pyrolysis to obtain energy-efficient products. Poultry manure pyrolysis is the intended technology of combustion for both ecological and energy generation purposes, obtaining coke and gas fuel. The waste subjected to pyrolysis had a behaviour very close to that of the inferior coal. This is also confirmed by the elemental analysis; high moisture value raising issues when direct combustion is used. The combustion of the poultry manure through various technologies, including pyrolysis, using also another fuel, is a secondary result. Waste management represents a current major concern, especially for modern society who faces the pressing problem of their storage. Thermal treatment is a solution adopted in several circumstances. The results obtained show that waste behavior is very close to that of inferior coal. Power consumption for pyrolysis process falls within satisfactory limits; bellow the heat obtained by burning pyrolysis products. Pyrolysis fuel products, represented by semi-coke and coke, are likely to be used to produce energy. The paper presents a practical way of economic and ecological exploitation of the garbage from the poultry farms. © 2018, International Multidisciplinary Scientific Geoconference. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Energy characteristic; Energy valorization; Heat consumption; Poultry manure; Pyrolysis process products

Authors: Kirilovs E., Kukle S., Zotova I., Nagle A.
Title: Structures of sound absorbing and thermal conductivity composite from raw renewable materials
Source title: International Multidisciplinary Scientific GeoConference Surveying Geology and Mining Ecology Management, SGEM
Affiliations: Institute of Design Technologies, Faculty of Material Science and Applied Chemistry, Riga Technical University, Latvia
Authors with affiliations: Kirilovs, E., Institute of Design Technologies, Faculty of Material Science and Applied Chemistry, Riga Technical University, Latvia; Kukle, S., Institute of Design Technologies, Faculty of Material Science and Applied Chemistry, Riga Technical University, Latvia; Zotova, I., Institute of Design Technologies, Faculty of Material Science and Applied Chemistry, Riga Technical University, Latvia; Nagle, A., Institute of Design Technologies, Faculty of Material Science and Applied Chemistry, Riga Technical University, Latvia
Abstract: Renewable raw materials, including natural fiber sources, are the future of storage resources with a variety of positive effects on both the planet ecosystem and the living and working environment, and the energy consumption of delivering the required functionality. Noise reduction is a significant component in creating a professional and suitable work environment as open-plan offices have become a quintessential trend of the 21st century. The most common solutions in noise control include installation of noise absorption barriers and acoustic systems. Bio-based materials show good sound absorption performances, at the same time leaving much lower environmental impact than traditionally used synthetic materials. One of the most important energy-saving types is to reduce energy consumption in buildings by insulating them. Research is focused on designating the optimal structure of composite materials in order to obtain a material with high textural qualities of the surface and a noise absorption level that reaches an average noise absorption coefficient value of αw = 0,5 in at least one set of specified frequencies. Following variables were analyzed in the research: the proportion rate of wool and wood shaving fibers, the panel layer thickness within 15mm – 25mm range, the number of layers per sample material. For measuring the acoustic properties of the sample materials an impedance tube was used. The measurements were carried out in 8 different sample categories, total of 40 samples were prepared and tested. After obtaining sound absorption coefficients, three samples with the highest sound absorption indices were selected for thermal conductivity measurements. © SGEM2018. All Rights Reserved.
Author Keywords: Noise absorbing materials; Noise reduction coefficient; Renewable biological composite materials; Thermal conductivity
